Subject:
 FW: Email
 
 
 
Hello all,
 
I am writing to address the series of postponed training sessions with Group M and Aflac during February, March, and April, for which I have not received compensation despite significant preparation time.
Detailed Session Breakdown
Group M Sessions (9 total)
·
 
Topic:
 Building an Inclusive Environment
·
 
Scheduled Dates:
o
 
February 24
o
 
March 14, 24, 28, 31
o
 
April 4, 11, 14, 25
·
 
Contracted Rate:
 $350 per session
·
 
Total Potential Earnings:
 $3,150
Aflac Postponed Sessions
·
 
"How Culture Influences Communication Styles"
o
 
Scheduled Date: February 26
o
 
Session Rate: $300
·
 
"Managing Bias in Talent Review"
o
 
Scheduled Date: March 6
o
 
Session Rate: $500
·
 
"Fostering Inclusive Leadership"
o
 
Scheduled Date: March 12
o
 
Session Rate: $350
·
 
Total Potential Aflac Earnings:
 $1,150
Total Uncompensated Earnings: $4,300
Compensation Proposal
While recognizing the unprecedented challenges we are experiencing, I propose a fair resolution based on the following considerations:
1.
       
Substantial Preparation Time:
 Significant effort was invested in preparing for these sessions.
2.
       
SOW Flexibility:
 Existing contract language supports compensation considerations.
3.
       
Cancellation Policy Alignment:
 Proposing compensation at 50% of the original session rate.
Proposed Compensation: $2,150
Negotiation Openness
I am committed to maintaining a professional and collaborative relationship. I am open to discussing a mutually agreeable compensation arrangement that recognizes the time and expertise invested while supporting our continued business partnership.
Next Steps
I welcome the opportunity to discuss this matter further and find a resolution that works for both parties.
Thank you for your careful consideration.

subject: Coaching & Mentoring: A Powerful Connection
body:
Coaching & Mentoring: A Powerful Connection
 
View this email in your browser
 
 
 
 
 
Coaching and mentoring are deeply connected.  
All great mentors use coaching skills to ask powerful questions, offer constructive feedback, and support their mentee's growth. This month, we’re exploring 
how coaching principles can enhance mentoring relationships
, making them 
more impactful
 and 
transformative
. As we celebrate five years of 
Bridging Differences for Better Mentoring,
 we’re reminded that the ability to coach through differences is key to fostering strong, inclusive mentoring connections.
Below, you'll find a variety of resources to help you strengthen your coaching skills within your mentoring relationships. Whether you're looking to refine your questioning techniques, provide more effective feedback, or navigate challenges with confidence! 
Mentor on,
The Center for Mentoring Excellence Team
 
As we celebrate 
five years
 of 
Bridging Differences for Better Mentoring
, we’re inspired to 
look ahead
. The work of bridging differences is more critical than ever in today’s diverse and interconnected world. We’re excited to:
Continue equipping mentors and mentees with new tools and resources.
Expand conversations around inclusivity and belonging.
Inspire the next generation of mentoring champions.
Thank you for being part of this journey. 
Together, we’re creating a future where mentoring relationships thrive across differences. 
Here’s to the next five years—and beyond!
 
 
Did you know we offer leadership coaching?
 
Our CEO, Lisa Fain, has openings for
 two
 
new coaching clients in June and July
! At the Center for Mentoring Excellence, we specialize in
 transformative leadership coaching
—whether as a complement to our mentoring programs or as a stand-alone tool for organizational and personal growth. Under Lisa’s expert guidance, our coaching services are designed to 
elevate leadership capabilities, enhance performance, and drive meaningful change
 within your organization. 
Learn more here
. 
 
In 
episode 18
 of our Thought Leader Conversation Series, Lisa Fain sits down with 
Professor David Clutterbuck
—global authority on 
coaching and mentoring
—to unpack the evolving intersection of these two related, but distinct learning relationships.  From the power of context and co-learning in mentoring to engaging mature coaches with mentoring mindsets, this conversation is packed with insight, humor, and practical wisdom. 
Watch the recording here
. 
Don’t miss 
April’s Thought Leader Conversation
 as Lisa and 
Javier Peña
 explore how 
harmony in mentoring
 and leadership skills can elevate your mentoring relationships. 
Register today
! 
 
Coaching and mentoring are essential to leadership development
, helping organizations build trust, adaptability, and stronger leaders. This study explores how companies that embed these practices into their culture see better talent retention, business performance, and leadership outcomes. Discover how coaching increases overall leadership effectiveness by reading the full study 
here
. 
 
 
If you’re looking to 
deepen your understanding of coaching in mentoring
, check out these three books by our 
March Thought Leader
,  David Clutterbuck, s. 
Coaching the Team at Work
 explores the complexities of team coaching with evidence-based strategies and practical tools. 
Everyone Needs a Mentor
 breaks down the fundamentals of mentoring, offering a guide to building impactful mentoring programs. Finally, 
Coaching and Mentoring: A Journey
 takes a reflective look at David’s 45-year contribution to the field, compiling key models and frameworks that have shaped modern coaching and mentoring practices.  
 
 
 "
Coaching and mentoring are not about teaching people to be something they are not; they are about helping them remove the obstacles that prevent them from being their best selves.
"
 This quote by Timothy Gallwey highlights the 
developmental
 and 
supportive 
roles both coaching and mentoring play in unlocking potential. 
 
UPCOMING EVENTS
Visit our LinkTree
 for upcoming events
 
CalSAE Elevate Conference
Peer Mentoring for Engagement and Retention: Strengthening Association Communities
with Lisa Fain
April 6-9, 2025 
Monterey Marriott 
350 Calle Principal, Monterey, CA 93940
Lisa will be speaking on April 7 at 3:45 PM PT 
at the 
CalSAE Elevate Conference
 in scenic Monterey, California. Her session, "
Peer Mentoring for Engagement and Retention: Strengthening Association Communities,
" will explore strategies to enhance engagement and build stronger association communities through peer mentoring.
 
 
Thought Leader Conversation
Harmony in Mentoring
with Javier Pena
Tuesday April 15, 2025
11am PST | 2pm EST 
Register Here
In our upcoming 
April Thought Leader Conversation
, CEO Lisa Fain sits down with 
Javier Pena
. Musician, keynote speaker, and founder of 
Leading in Tune™
, Javier Peña uses the principles of music to inspire leadership, teamwork, and mentorship. Drawing from his experience leading a diverse group of musicians to national recognition, he’ll share how 
harmony—both in music and mentoring—can foster stronger, more connected relationships
. Join us for an inspiring conversation on the power of rhythm and connection in mentoring.
 
 
Thought Leader Conversation
Goal Setting in Mentoring
with Jason VanDevere
Tuesday June 10, 2025
11am PST | 2pm EST 
Register Here
In our upcoming 
June Thought Leader Conversation
, CEO Lisa Fain sits down with 
Jason VanDevere
, founder of 
Goal Crazy
, is an entrepreneur, business owner, author, and personal development coach passionate about helping others turn aspirations into reality through intentional goal setting. As he prepares to release his new book, 
Do Your Dream: The Step-by-Step Process to Discover Your Perfect Business Idea and Launch It This Year
, Jason joins Lisa Fain to discuss how structured 
goal setting
 can enhance mentoring relationships
, drive personal and professional growth, and ensure lasting success. Don’t miss this opportunity to gain practical tools and insights to take your mentoring—and goal achievement—to the next level!
 
 
2026
IMA Biennial Conference
Mentoring Metamorphosis: Growing and Flourishing in an Era of Change
May 12-14, 2026
University of Florida | 
St Petersburg, FL
Save the Dates 
for 
International Mentoring Association
 (IMA) 
2026 Biennial Conference
, taking place 
May 12-14, 2026, in St. Petersburg, FL
, at the University of Florida. The conference theme is, "
Mentoring Metamorphosis: Growing and Flourishing in an Era of Change
," where IMA will explore the evolving landscape of mentoring and how we can adapt, innovate, and thrive in shifting environments. 
More details coming soon! 
  
We'd love your feedback on our newsletters or suggestions on things you would like us to include. 
Click here
 to share your thoughts.

 or

subject: Uncertainty is inevitable—how you respond makes all the difference.
body:
Whether you need a quick learning boost, an in-depth training, or a transformational certification, we’ve got you covered.
 
Leading With Purpose in Uncertain Times
 
In today’s unpredictable landscape, 
bold and strategic leadership
 is more important than ever. Scaling back or stalling diversity, equity, and inclusion efforts can risk legal challenges, reputational damage, and missed opportunities. 
Now is the time to move forward with intention.

subject: The latest from our podcast | Q1 2025
body:
Press play on a few of our favorite episodes from the past several months. 
March 24, 2025  ·  
View in browser
 
Hear the latest research and ideas from the faculty of the Kellogg School of Management at Northwestern University
Good day!
There's only a brief time in the morning that's really 
mine
 these days: it begins when I open my eyes and ends when my five-year-old's feet hit the ground. We’re talkin’ an hour, tops, so I pop in the earbuds and start raking up socks strewn about the house. 
The Insightful Leader podcast was built for such multitaskers. It’s quick (15 minutes, give or take) and full of easy-to-digest ingest tips straight from the faculty at Kellogg. Every few months, we’ll send you a newsletter with some of our latest episodes. In this edition, hear about research and insights on AI, delegation, the likability trap, and more. Enjoy!
Yours,
Laura Pavin
Multimedia Editor, 
Kellogg Insight
Communication
How to Get Delegation Right (3-Part Series)
 
In this edition of The Insightful Leader’s “Ask Insight” series, we discuss this hard-to-master skill with a Kellogg professor and executive coach.

subject: FW: Examples for Ultieg
body:
Look at these examples. Let me know what you think. Thanks,
 
LBJ
 
From:
 Larry Baker <lbjbaker1@gmail.com> 
Sent:
 Sunday, March 30, 2025 10:47 AM
To:
 Larry Baker <l.baker@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Examples for Ultieg
 
Cross-Generational Developmental Conversations
Scenario 1: Boomer Manager & Gen Z Employee
Context:
 Marketing department of a retail company 
Topic:
 Communication style and formality 
Characters:
 Patricia (59, Baby Boomer, Marketing Director) and Tyler (23, Gen Z, Marketing Coordinator)
Conversation:
Patricia:
 Tyler, I wanted to chat about your communication style in client meetings. I've noticed you tend to use casual language and abbreviations that some of our more traditional clients might not understand.
Tyler:
 Yeah, I get that. I guess I'm just communicating how I normally would. Is it really that big of a deal?
Patricia:
 In some contexts, it can be. Many of our established clients expect a certain level of formality. It signals professionalism to them.
Tyler:
 That's interesting. I actually find that being authentic and speaking naturally helps me build better connections. My generation values authenticity over formality.
Patricia:
 I appreciate that perspective. Perhaps we can find a middle ground. Could you consider adjusting your style for certain clients while maintaining your authentic approach with others?
Tyler:
 I could definitely be more mindful of my audience. Maybe you could help me identify which clients might prefer more formal communication?
Patricia:
 That's a great solution. I'll share my insights about our client preferences, and perhaps you could teach me some of the more effective casual communication techniques that work well with younger clients.
Tyler:
 I'd be happy to! I think we could both learn from each other's strengths here.
Scenario 2: Millennial Manager & Boomer Employee
Context:
 Financial services firm 
Topic:
 Adapting to technological changes 
Characters:
 Jessica (38, Millennial, Team Lead) and Robert (62, Baby Boomer, Financial Analyst)
Conversation:
Jessica:
 Robert, I've noticed you're still using the old spreadsheet method for client data analysis rather than the new CRM system we implemented last month.
Robert:
 The spreadsheet system has worked perfectly fine for the past 15 years. I can get the same results without having to learn an entirely new system.
Jessica:
 I understand you've developed efficient systems over your career. However, the new CRM offers features that significantly speed up analysis and allows for better team collaboration.
Robert:
 I've built my career on accuracy and thoroughness. I'm concerned that rushing to adopt new technology might compromise that quality.
Jessica:
 I deeply respect your commitment to quality. What if we approach this as an opportunity to combine your analytical expertise with new tools that can enhance what you already do well?
Robert:
 I suppose I've been resisting because I'm worried about the learning curve. At this stage in my career, starting from scratch feels challenging.
Jessica:
 That's a valid concern. What if I arranged for one-on-one training sessions? Your experience is incredibly valuable to our team, and combining that with new technological capabilities would be powerful.
Robert:
 I appreciate you recognizing that. I'm willing to give it a try with proper support. Perhaps I could also document some of the analytical approaches I've developed that might be integrated into the new system.
Jessica:
 That would be excellent! Your expertise could help us customize the CRM to better serve our specific needs.
Scenario 3: Gen X Colleagues of Different Racial Backgrounds
Context:
 University administration 
Topic:
 Inclusive leadership and cultural awareness 
Characters:
 Marcus (48, Black, Associate Dean) and Diane (45, White, Department Chair)
Conversation:
Marcus:
 Diane, I wanted to discuss something I observed in yesterday's faculty meeting. When Professor Johnson, who is Korean American, was speaking about her research, she was interrupted several times.
Diane:
 I noticed that too, but I wasn't sure if I should step in. I sometimes worry about overstepping or making assumptions about what others might need.
Marcus:
 I understand that concern. As leaders in our department, though, I think we need to be more proactive about ensuring everyone's voice is heard equally.
Diane:
 You're right. I realize I may have hesitated because I'm sometimes unsure about how to address these moments without making them more awkward. How do you approach these situations?
Marcus:
 For me, it's about establishing clear meeting norms from the beginning. I've found that simple statements like "Let's make sure we hear everyone's complete thoughts before responding" can make a difference.
Diane:
 That's helpful. I think I also need to become more comfortable with the discomfort that can come with addressing these moments directly.
Marcus:
 Absolutely. And from my experience as a Black man in academia, I can tell you that the discomfort of having someone interrupt these patterns is far less than the discomfort of being repeatedly interrupted or overlooked.
Diane:
 That's an important perspective I hadn't fully considered. I'd appreciate your feedback as I work on being more proactive. Maybe we could collaborate on developing some departmental guidelines for inclusive discussions?
Marcus:
 I'd be happy to work on that together. By combining our different perspectives and experiences, we could create something that really addresses the needs of our diverse faculty.
Scenario 4: Gen Z Manager & Millennial Employee
Context:
 Tech startup 
Topic:
 Work-life boundaries and productivity 
Characters:
 Zoe (27, Gen Z, Product Manager) and Miguel (35, Millennial, Software Developer)
Conversation:
Zoe:
 Miguel, I noticed you've been responding to Slack messages at midnight and sending emails on weekends. I'm concerned about potential burnout.
Miguel:
 I appreciate your concern, but I'm just trying to stay on top of everything. This project is important, and I want to make sure we meet our deadlines.
Zoe:
 I understand the commitment to the project, but our company values sustainable productivity. We don't expect people to be available 24/7.
Miguel:
 In my previous companies, responsiveness was highly valued. It showed dedication to the job.
Zoe:
 That's interesting. For my generation, we've seen the negative effects of always-on culture. Research shows that proper rest actually improves overall productivity and creativity.
Miguel:
 I guess I'm still carrying expectations from previous workplace cultures. Sometimes I worry that if I'm not constantly available, it might seem like I'm not committed enough.
Zoe:
 Your commitment is evident in the quality of your work, not in when you respond to messages. What if we establish some team agreements about communication hours?
Miguel:
 That could help set clearer expectations. To be honest, it would be nice to disconnect more without feeling guilty.
Zoe:
 Exactly. Let's work together to define what healthy boundaries look like for our team. Your experience is valuable, and I want to make sure you're set up for long-term success here, not just short-term output.
Miguel:
 I appreciate that. It's actually refreshing to have a manager who prioritizes wellbeing alongside performance.
Scenario 5: Gen X Manager & Gen Alpha Intern
Context:
 Environmental nonprofit 
Topic:
 Professional communication and expectations 
Characters:
 Lisa (44, Gen X, Program Director) and Aiden (16, Gen Alpha, Summer Intern)
Conversation:
Lisa:
 Aiden, I wanted to check in about your first few weeks with us. How are you finding the experience?
Aiden:
 It's been cool! I really like the mission. But sometimes I'm not sure what I'm supposed to be doing or if I'm doing things right.
Lisa:
 Thanks for sharing that. Could you tell me more about where you're feeling uncertain?
Aiden:
 Well, like yesterday when you asked me to "circle back" with the volunteers, I wasn't really sure what that meant. And sometimes I feel like I should be doing more, but I don't want to mess anything up.
Lisa:
 I see. I should be more clear with my instructions and avoid jargon. "Circling back" just means following up with them about their availability.
Aiden:
 That makes sense. Also, is it okay to message you with questions? I use messaging apps for everything, but I'm not sure what's professional.
Lisa:
 Great question. For quick clarifications, messaging is perfect. For more complex discussions or anything involving program decisions, I'd prefer we talk in person or schedule a video call.
Aiden:
 Got it. That helps a lot.
Lisa:
 I'm curious - what methods of communication do you find most effective?
Aiden:
 I like how we use different channels for different types of communication here. But maybe having some examples of professional messages would help me understand the expectations better.
Lisa:
 That's an excellent suggestion. I can put together some templates and examples. And Aiden, please know that asking questions is exactly what you should be doing as an intern. It shows engagement and a desire to learn.
Aiden:
 Thanks! I'm really excited to learn how things work in a professional environment. It's pretty different from school.
Lisa:
 That's why internships are so valuable. And I appreciate your digital fluency – it brings a fresh perspective to our team. Let's set up a quick check-in meeting each week to address any questions and make sure you're getting the most out of this experience.

subject: Examples for Ultieg
body:
Cross-Generational Developmental Conversations
Scenario 1: Boomer Manager & Gen Z Employee
Context:
 Marketing department of a retail company 
Topic:
 Communication style and formality 
Characters:
 Patricia (59, Baby Boomer, Marketing Director) and Tyler (23, Gen Z, Marketing Coordinator)
Conversation:
Patricia:
 Tyler, I wanted to chat about your communication style in client meetings. I've noticed you tend to use casual language and abbreviations that some of our more traditional clients might not understand.
Tyler:
 Yeah, I get that. I guess I'm just communicating how I normally would. Is it really that big of a deal?
Patricia:
 In some contexts, it can be. Many of our established clients expect a certain level of formality. It signals professionalism to them.
Tyler:
 That's interesting. I actually find that being authentic and speaking naturally helps me build better connections. My generation values authenticity over formality.
Patricia:
 I appreciate that perspective. Perhaps we can find a middle ground. Could you consider adjusting your style for certain clients while maintaining your authentic approach with others?
Tyler:
 I could definitely be more mindful of my audience. Maybe you could help me identify which clients might prefer more formal communication?
Patricia:
 That's a great solution. I'll share my insights about our client preferences, and perhaps you could teach me some of the more effective casual communication techniques that work well with younger clients.
Tyler:
 I'd be happy to! I think we could both learn from each other's strengths here.
Scenario 2: Millennial Manager & Boomer Employee
Context:
 Financial services firm 
Topic:
 Adapting to technological changes 
Characters:
 Jessica (38, Millennial, Team Lead) and Robert (62, Baby Boomer, Financial Analyst)
Conversation:
Jessica:
 Robert, I've noticed you're still using the old spreadsheet method for client data analysis rather than the new CRM system we implemented last month.
Robert:
 The spreadsheet system has worked perfectly fine for the past 15 years. I can get the same results without having to learn an entirely new system.
Jessica:
 I understand you've developed efficient systems over your career. However, the new CRM offers features that significantly speed up analysis and allows for better team collaboration.
Robert:
 I've built my career on accuracy and thoroughness. I'm concerned that rushing to adopt new technology might compromise that quality.
Jessica:
 I deeply respect your commitment to quality. What if we approach this as an opportunity to combine your analytical expertise with new tools that can enhance what you already do well?
Robert:
 I suppose I've been resisting because I'm worried about the learning curve. At this stage in my career, starting from scratch feels challenging.
Jessica:
 That's a valid concern. What if I arranged for one-on-one training sessions? Your experience is incredibly valuable to our team, and combining that with new technological capabilities would be powerful.
Robert:
 I appreciate you recognizing that. I'm willing to give it a try with proper support. Perhaps I could also document some of the analytical approaches I've developed that might be integrated into the new system.
Jessica:
 That would be excellent! Your expertise could help us customize the CRM to better serve our specific needs.
Scenario 3: Gen X Colleagues of Different Racial Backgrounds
Context:
 University administration 
Topic:
 Inclusive leadership and cultural awareness 
Characters:
 Marcus (48, Black, Associate Dean) and Diane (45, White, Department Chair)
Conversation:
Marcus:
 Diane, I wanted to discuss something I observed in yesterday's faculty meeting. When Professor Johnson, who is Korean American, was speaking about her research, she was interrupted several times.
Diane:
 I noticed that too, but I wasn't sure if I should step in. I sometimes worry about overstepping or making assumptions about what others might need.
Marcus:
 I understand that concern. As leaders in our department, though, I think we need to be more proactive about ensuring everyone's voice is heard equally.
Diane:
 You're right. I realize I may have hesitated because I'm sometimes unsure about how to address these moments without making them more awkward. How do you approach these situations?
Marcus:
 For me, it's about establishing clear meeting norms from the beginning. I've found that simple statements like "Let's make sure we hear everyone's complete thoughts before responding" can make a difference.
Diane:
 That's helpful. I think I also need to become more comfortable with the discomfort that can come with addressing these moments directly.
Marcus:
 Absolutely. And from my experience as a Black man in academia, I can tell you that the discomfort of having someone interrupt these patterns is far less than the discomfort of being repeatedly interrupted or overlooked.
Diane:
 That's an important perspective I hadn't fully considered. I'd appreciate your feedback as I work on being more proactive. Maybe we could collaborate on developing some departmental guidelines for inclusive discussions?
Marcus:
 I'd be happy to work on that together. By combining our different perspectives and experiences, we could create something that really addresses the needs of our diverse faculty.

subject: The case for muting the boss
body:
Plus: authenticity at work, innovation at startups, and green bonds. 
March 30, 2025  ·  
View in browser
 
The latest research and ideas from the Kellogg School of Management at Northwestern University
How to Encourage Authenticity at Work
 
The right conditions can help people, particularly those from marginalized groups, feel more comfortable with expressing their true selves.
 
The Case for Muting the Boss
 
When discussing business strategy, leaders should leave room for new voices, who could spur the next big idea.
 
From the Archives
The Desire to Be Acquired Is Stifling Innovation at Startups
 
The result is “more-conventional, less-radical, less-novel innovation,” adding a wrinkle to antitrust debates.
 
From the Archives
Do Green Bonds Actually Lead to Rosy Returns?
 
And are the companies that issue them truly addressing climate issues?

subject: Resources & Networking for Faith ERGs 🚩
body:
Christian, Interfaith, Jewish & Muslim Roundtables
 
 
Resources & Networking for Faith ERGs
 
Christian, Interfaith, Jewish & Muslim Roundtables
 
Dear Larry Baker, 
For the first time, 
Dare to Overcome
 (DTO) will begin with resource and networking roundtables for the four most prevalent faith employee resource groups (ERGs): Christian, Interfaith, Jewish, and Muslim.
Members and leaders of faith ERGs will have the opportunity to network and learn from their peers as well as benefit from the resources and experience of the convening sponsors: 
Coca-Cola Consolidated
, 
Interfaith America
, 
Clal
, and the 
El-Hibri Foundation
.
 
DTO is the go-to annual gathering for Fortune 500 company ERGs, corporate chaplains, and other faith-and-belief workplace initiatives to share best practices and celebrate achievements. Join us!
Brian Grim
President, Religious Freedom & Business Foundation
Global Chair, Dare to Overcome 
 
Monday Deadline: 2025 Faith-Friendly Workplace REDI Survey
 
 
The REDI Index is the premier benchmarking measure of an organization’s commitment to including religion & belief as part of its overall people and belonging initiatives. You can 
download a pdf of the questionnaire here
. If you want to participate, please request a personalized survey for your organization by
 
email
 that can be saved and accessed on separate sittings or devices using the unique link that will be provided.
DEADLINE: March 31, 2025 
(extensions possible upon request)
REQUEST REDI Survey
 
Also, join us in London

"Fostering Inclusive Leadership"
Scheduled Date: March 12
Session Rate: $350
Total Potential Aflac Earnings:
 $1,150
Total Uncompensated Earnings: $4,650
Compensation Proposal
While recognizing the unprecedented challenges we are experiencing, I propose a fair resolution based on the following considerations:
Substantial Preparation Time:
 Significant effort was invested in preparing for these sessions.
SOW Flexibility:
 Existing contract language supports compensation considerations.
Cancellation Policy Alignment:
 Proposing compensation at 50% of the original session rate.
Proposed Compensation: $2,325
Negotiation Openness
I am committed to maintaining a professional and collaborative relationship. I am open to discussing a mutually agreeable compensation arrangement that recognizes the time and expertise invested while supporting our continued business partnership.
Next Steps
I welcome the opportunity to discuss this matter further and find a resolution that works for both parties.
Thank you for your careful consideration.

subject: Let’s change the narrative…
body:
Resources to help! 
͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌  
 
formerly Texthelp
March 2025 
Larry Your monthly roundup of tips, tricks, resources & more!  
Changing the narrative on neurodiversity
 
Over the last week people and businesses around the world have been getting involved in Neurodiversity Celebration Week - a worldwide initiative that challenges stereotypes about neurological differences. 
The week may be over but the mission to change the narrative is not. 
Here’s some resources to help you challenge stigma in your own organization - feel free to share them with your colleagues!
 
 
Combat stigma
 
Our Founder shares
 four ways employers can combat stigmas surrounding neurodiversity
 
 
Grow understanding
 
Our neurodivergent friend Cory shares 
six facts he wishes people understood about neurodiversity
 
 
Celebrate difference
 
Four neurodivergent individuals share the talents they bring to the workplace
 
 
Take action
 
Nine experts from leading brands share their insights to help you advance neuroinclusion
 
It's not too late…
 
Yesterday three global brands joined our webinar to share the neuroinclusive strategies helping them to unlock the potential of all employees. Catch up on the recording and gain strategies to bring back to your own organization.
 
Sign up now 
Neurodiversity & web accessibility… 
Creating accessible websites means recognizing how different people process information - and understanding how design can make information processing easier. 
For example people with Autism benefit from predictable patterns. Those with ADHD benefit from clear, structured layouts. 
Here, the A11y Collective shares best practices for cognitive accessibility
. The tips they share benefit not only those with neurological differences - but everyone! 
 
Championing cognitive accessibility with ReachDeck
 
Our digital inclusion tool, ReachDeck, helps to make websites easier to access and understand. With the ReachDeck Auditor, find accessibility and readability errors at scale. With the ReachDeck Editor, write content that’s easier for everyone to understand. 
Discover more
.
 
  
Behind the scenes at Everway
 
Over the past couple of weeks our Everway teams from across the globe have been getting together to connect, share ideas, and shape the future of our new brand. From Atlanta to London, 
here’s a behind-the-scenes look at some of the best moments from our all-company meetings
. 
 
We want to hear from you 
We want to give you content that you find useful. So, we'd love to hear from you. What topics would you love to see featured in this newsletter? Or do you have a good neuroinclusion story to tell? Your input will help us to bring you valuable content in return. 
 
Reach out to 
abby@texthelp.com
 and let us know!  
Kind regards, 
The Everway team 
formerly Texthelp

 to no longer receive emails from us.

subject: GroupM Timeline (corrected)
body:
I thought it might be useful to have a summary of GroupM’s timeline and shifts:
2/10/25: Emailed Larry first Project Assignment with start date of February 24
th
2/13: Lakisha notified us that they are not ready to start on February 24
th
 and it would “probably be the first or second week in March”. Notified Larry the same day via email
2/18:  We had an internal meeting with Group M. Lakisha said the earliest first session would be March 14
th
. Notified Larry via email. Sent Larry a revised PA with the first session being March 14
th
2/19: Received signed PA back from Larry
2/21: Larry asked me about a Spencer Stewart session. I asked Chuck about it, He confirmed that this should be added to the PA so I sent Larry a new PA which included the Spencer Stewart session on 3/6. The first GroupM session was still listed as 3/14.
3/5:  GroupM pushed back first session again and I notified Larry via email. Group I’m saying the earliest would be March 21
st
3/17: GroupM pushed back the 2025 launch again, this time to “late April at the earliest”, I notified Larry
3/25: We still don’t have a firm start date. GroupM has checked off all but one task they needed to do before we can firm up that date. We have a meeting with them tomorrow (3/16) where hopefully this last task will be resolved (it has to do with their scheduling system).
 
 
Rebecca M. Parrilla
 
(MBA, Latina, LGBTQ, Mom)

subject: Learn How to Avoid I-9 Land Mines on April 2. Register Now
body:
Are your I-9 practices audit ready?
 
 
The stakes have never been higher for employers navigating Form I-9 compliance and immigration regulations. Are you confident your organization is fully prepared? 
I-9 compliance isn’t optional. Failing to follow the latest regulations can result in significant fines, legal exposure, and reputational damage. With recent executive orders amplifying enforcement efforts, your organization must understand the critical updates to stay protected. Secure your spot for the exclusive webinar, 
I-9 Land Mines: What You Don’t Know Will Cost You
, on 
Wednesday, April 2 from 1-2 p.m. ET
. 
Join SHRM’s CHRO and a legal expert as they break down the latest I-9 compliance updates and reveal actionable strategies to safeguard your workforce and operations.
In this webinar, you’ll gain: 
Knowledge of changing regulations and avoid costly missteps.
An understanding of the most frequent I-9 errors and how to correct them. 
Actionable steps to protect your organization and minimize risk.
Strategies to streamline I-9 processes and improve compliance.
Failure to act could cost far more than just penalties. Stay informed, stay compliant, and take the necessary steps to protect what matters most. 
Plus, be the first to get an exclusive preview of SHRM’s new I-9 toolkit on April 2. Once released, you can purchase the toolkit for $395 or 
join SHRM
 for $299 to access the toolkit and everything SHRM has to offer — expert resources, the HR Crisis Hotline, legal updates, and more. 
 
 
 
REGISTER NOW
 
 
Presenting Experts
 
 
 
 
Daniel Brown
Daniel Brown is a Partner at Fragomen’s Washington, DC office, and is part of the firm’s Government Strategies and Compliance Group. His experience includes counseling corporate clients on business immigration, compliance and enforcement matters, with a focus on I-9 and E-Verify issues. 
 
 
 
 
Jim Link
Jim Link is the CHRO for SHRM. As a sought-after speaker on the international stage, his insightful presentations delve into critical aspects of the contemporary workplace, including but not limited to inclusion, employee experience and engagement organizational culture, benefits strategies, and mental health advocacy. 
 
 
Already a member?
 Our records indicate that the email address l.baker@lcwmail.com isn’t matched to a current membership. Please contact our Customer Experience Team or update your account in the 
MySHRM section
 of the website after you log in.

subject: In Case You Missed It #57: Remote work strengthens employee relationships and more
body:
ICYMI 
 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
Greetings Larry,
To help you filter the signal from the noise, I curated the most valuable articles I came across recently in case you missed them.
“
Remote work strengthens employee relationships, HBR research suggests
” (Executive Grapevine)
Summary
Despite the ongoing push from major corporations like Amazon, Google, and JPMorgan Chase to bring employees back to the office, new research from the 
Harvard Business Review
 (HBR) suggests that remote work may actually enhance workplace relationships.
The study found that virtual interactions—particularly those that reveal glimpses of colleagues' personal lives, such as children interrupting calls or home backgrounds—can make employees appear more authentic, trustworthy, and relatable. This authenticity fosters both professional collaboration and personal connection, challenging the assumption that in-person work is necessary for strong workplace bonds.
While companies argue that physical proximity drives creativity and collaboration, many employees remain resistant, citing better work-life balance, increased productivity, and reduced stress when working remotely. Experts suggest that RTO policies should be task-based, allowing flexibility where possible rather than enforcing blanket mandates.
Dr. Gleb’s Take
The data is clear: forcing employees back to the office under the illusion that it strengthens relationships is a leadership failure. Authentic connections aren’t built in conference rooms—they’re built through trust, autonomy, and respect. This study proves that remote work doesn’t weaken relationships; it makes them more human.
Companies clinging to outdated in-office models aren’t promoting collaboration—they’re asserting control. The future of work is hybrid, flexible, and results-driven. Businesses that embrace this will thrive. Those that don’t will bleed talent to smarter competitors.
“
Local Heterogeneity in Artificial Intelligence Jobs Over Time and Space
” (SSRN)
Summary
This study analyzes how AI-related job opportunities have evolved across U.S. counties between 2014 and 2023. While traditional tech hubs like Santa Clara, CA, remain dominant, surprising growth has emerged in suburban and remote-friendly areas such as Maries, MO, and Hughes, SD—particularly in the post-lockdown era.
Key factors driving AI job adoption include a higher concentration of STEM graduates, a tight labor market, and strong patent activity. Conversely, regions with heavy manufacturing and high employee turnover see slower AI adoption. The findings highlight how AI’s economic benefits are unevenly distributed, emphasizing the role of local education, innovation, and labor market conditions. The paper also suggests that place-based policies could help attract AI talent and investments, reducing regional disparities.
Dr. Gleb’s Take
The AI job market isn’t just about Silicon Valley anymore—it’s decentralizing, and fast. This study confirms that suburban and remote-friendly regions are becoming unexpected winners in AI job growth. The message for policymakers is clear: if you want to compete in the AI economy, invest in STEM education and innovation incentives now, and support remote work.
Manufacturing-heavy regions resisting AI adoption and opposing remote work are setting themselves up for long-term economic decline. The future belongs to remote-friendly areas that embrace AI, not just as a tool, but as a driver of regional economic transformation. Place-based policies aren’t optional; they’re a necessity for staying competitive in the AI-driven world.
“
What’s the Goal of the Goal?
” (Behavioral Scientist)
Summary
This article explores how focusing on short-term metrics can sometimes undermine an organization’s true mission. It illustrates this with several examples, including a car dealership aggressively pressuring customers for high satisfaction scores—so much so that it turned a positive buying experience into a frustrating ordeal. The dealership’s goal should have been to improve customer satisfaction, but instead, they prioritized gaming the rating system.
Another example involves Eurostar’s decision to spend 6 billion GBP to cut travel time between London and Paris by 20 minutes. While this technically met their goal, it ignored the bigger question: was this the best way to improve passenger experience? Alternatives like Wi-Fi or enhanced service could have been cheaper and more effective.
The article also discusses a government program to help disabled veterans get student loan forgiveness. Initially, the goal was to increase application rates, but after stepping back and asking “What’s the goal of the goal?” officials realized they could eliminate the application process altogether—dramatically improving efficiency and veterans’ financial security.
Ultimately, the piece argues that before pursuing any goal, leaders should ask: “What’s the bigger purpose?” This approach can prevent wasted effort and uncover simpler, more impactful solutions.
Dr. Gleb’s Take
This article nails a fundamental leadership failure: chasing arbitrary metrics instead of real impact. Too many organizations mistake numbers for progress, blindly optimizing for a flawed target. Whether it’s forcing customers into fake high ratings, spending billions on unnecessary upgrades, or drowning people in bureaucracy, the pattern is the same—losing sight of the actual mission.
Smart leaders step back and ask, “What are we really trying to achieve?” Those who don’t end up wasting resources, frustrating employees, and missing out on better solutions. If your strategy is just hitting numbers instead of delivering real value, you’re not leading—you’re just checking boxes.
What did you think of my take on these articles? Look forward to hearing from you, simply reply to this email with your thoughts.
Decisively yours,
Dr. Gleb
Dr. Gleb Tsipursky
CEO of Disaster Avoidance Experts
Let's Connect!
Disaster Avoidance Experts is a social enterprise dedicated to promoting science-based truth-seeking and wise decision-making. All profits are donated to 
Intentional Insights
, an educational 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization, and its 
Pro-Truth Pledge
 project.

subject: Navigate Uncertainty: Start Your DEI Risk Assessment Today
body:
The Winters Group's comprehensive DEI Risk Assessment goes beyond simple regulatory and legal compliance to look at the full picture.
 
Evaluate Your DEI Approach with a Risk Assessment
Today’s fast-changing social and regulatory landscape means organizations are navigating increasing uncertainty—particularly when it comes to how they approach diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI).
 
Poorly designed or reactive DEI strategies—or eliminating programs altogether—can create significant risks: legal challenges, reputational damage, difficulty attracting and retaining talent, financial setbacks, and missed opportunities. Recent actions by the U.S. Administration targeting DEI initiatives have added another layer of complexity and concern.
 
As experts in change management, organizational culture, and diversity, equity, and inclusion, The Winters Group offers a comprehensive risk assessment process that goes beyond simple legal compliance to identify the full spectrum of potential vulnerabilities—and opportunities—for your organization.
Start your risk assessment today
 
Don't Settle for Only Part of the Picture:
 
Leaders need a complete and unbiased understanding of the facts to successfully navigate today’s rapidly evolving business landscape. While many DEI risk assessments focus primarily on legal or regulatory exposure, that’s only part of the picture. Overlooking reputational, organizational, and financial risks can leave companies exposed.
 
Legal Risks:
 Ensure that all DEI initiatives are aligned with existing civil rights laws and are framed around business imperatives.
 
Organizational Culture Risks: 
Identify opportunities and gaps that impact employee retention, engagement, team collaboration, conflict management, leadership, psychological safety, trust-building, decision-making, change management, and more.
 
Compliance Risks: 
Proactively align programs with federal, state, and local compliance standards.
 
Reputational Risks:
 Understand the potential impact of public sentiment, especially among the core communities you serve.
Assess your risk today
 
 
 
 
 
The Winters Group, 8116 South Tryon Street, Ste. B3-260, Charlotte, North Carolina 28273, United States

subject: 👗 🥻 👳🏻 Redefining professionalism with respect
body:
Continue reading to learn how to create a culturally responsive dress code for your organization. ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Hello Larry!
 
👋
 
Welcome Back
Earlier this week, we explored how traditional dress codes may be unintentionally excluding employees from expressing their cultural identities—and how that quiet exclusion can erode belonging. 
 
Now let’s talk about what you 
can
 do, as a forward-thinking leader, to challenge outdated norms and create a more inclusive environment that works for everyone. 
 
🧭
 
Strategy 1: Reevaluate the Origins of Your Current Dress Code
Ask yourself and your leadership team: 
When was this policy created—and who was it designed for?
Often, dress codes are inherited from decades-old corporate standards that centered a narrow view of professionalism. This is your opportunity to reassess whether your current policy truly reflects your workforce 
today
.
 
📣
 
Strategy 2: Involve Employees in the Conversation
Inclusion starts with listening. Create safe spaces for employees to share feedback about how current dress code policies affect them.
Consider launching a brief survey or hosting listening sessions. By involving your teams in policy evolution, you build trust, increase buy-in, and gain insights into diverse dress norms that you may not have considered.
 
 
📄
 
Strategy 3: Define Professionalism with Cultural Flexibility
Yes, professionalism matters—but it doesn’t have to be rigid or monocultural. The key is to develop clear, inclusive dress code guidelines that accommodate religious or cultural attire (e.g., hijabs, turbans, saris, dashikis, etc.) while maintaining appropriateness for the role.
Clarity helps prevent subjective interpretations and ensures consistency across departments.
 
🤝
 
Strategy 4: Allow for Individual Accommodation
Make it known that your organization supports respectful accommodations when needed.
For example: Religious head coverings, gender-affirming attire, or cultural garments worn for traditional observance should be welcomed—not penalized. This reinforces a message of respect and dignity for all employees.
 
Strategy 5: Lead by Example with Cultural Competence Training
Ensure that leaders and managers are equipped with the tools to understand, appreciate, and support cultural differences—including attire. 
 A culturally competent leader sets the tone for inclusion from the top down.  
 
Dress codes may seem small—but they speak volumes. When employees no longer have to choose between authenticity and acceptance, they show up more engaged, more confident, and more committed to your mission. 
By implementing culturally inclusive policies, you send a powerful message: 
👥
 
Everyone belongs here—exactly as they are.
 
  
📞
 
Let’s Build This Together
If you’re ready to take the next step to create a truly inclusive organization, I’d love to support you. 
Schedule a complimentary strategy call
 with me today, and let’s explore how 
Mastering Cultural Differences
 can help you lead systemic, lasting change.
 
📅
 
Book Your Free Call Now
 
 
 
Together, we’ll create a workplace where every identity is seen—and every voice is heard. 
Bye for now, 
Luiza
___________________________________
 
Luiza Dreasher, Founder and CEO (she/her/hers)
Mastering Cultural Differences 
I work with leaders who want to create a work environment where all employees feel valued and want to stay.
At 
Mastering Cultural Differences LLC,
 we are committed to helping organizations build inclusive, culturally competent workplaces where every individual feels valued and respected. Through highly customized programs, we equip teams with knowledge and skills to help them connect and collaborate more effectively across differences. From:

 Tuesday, March 25, 2025 7:53 PM
To:
 Rebecca Parrilla <r.parrilla@lcwmail.com>; Andrea Wicks Bowles <a.wicksbowles@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 RE: Cancellations for Group M and Aflac
 
RP, 
 
Thanks for this information. What was the agreement with contractors before they decided to change the terms?
 
Andrea,
Can you share this information on Aflac’s timeline of changes.
 
Thanks,
 
LBJ
 
From:
 Rebecca Parrilla <
r.parrilla@lcwmail.com
> 
Sent:
 Tuesday, March 25, 2025 12:30 PM
To:
 Andrea Wicks Bowles <
a.wicksbowles@lcwmail.com
>; Larry Baker <
l.baker@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 RE: Cancellations for Group M and Aflac
 
I think Nicole should be included because she is the decision maker, no? 
 
I thought it might be useful to have a summary of GroupM’s timeline and shifts:
2/24/25: Emailed Larry first Project Assignment with start date of February 24
th
2/13: Lakisha notified us that they are not ready to start on February 24
th
 and it would “probably be the first or second week in March”. Notified Larry the same day via email
2/18:  We had an internal meeting with Group M. Lakisha said the earliest first session would be March 14
th
. Notified Larry via email. Sent Larry a revised PA with the first session being March 14
th
2/19: Received signed PA back from Larry
2/21: Larry asked me about a Spencer Stewart session. I asked Chuck about it, He confirmed that this should be added to the PA so I sent Larry a new PA which included the Spencer Stewart session on 3/6. The first GroupM session was still listed as 3/14.
3/5:  GroupM pushed back first session again and I notified Larry via email. Group I’m saying the earliest would be March 21
st
3/17: GroupM pushed back the 2025 launch again, this time to “late April at the earliest”, I notified Larry
3/25: We still don’t have a firm start date. GroupM has checked off all but one task they needed to do before we can firm up that date. We have a meeting with them tomorrow (3/16) where hopefully this last task will be resolved (it has to do with their scheduling system).
 
 
 
Rebecca M. Parrilla
 
(MBA, Latina, LGBTQ, Mom)
(she/her) 
Why pronouns matter
Head of Client Solutions
LCW

 Andrea Wicks Bowles <
a.wicksbowles@lcwmail.com

l.baker@lcwmail.com
>

I hear you Larry.  Let me check the calendars.  I think we should include Nicole in the as well.  Is that cool with you?  Or would you rather just us three??
 
Cheers~

Right. So the terms in a PA I sent an external consultant in early March, the terms were:
 
Session Cancellation Policy
LCW will pay 25% of the rate for scheduled sessions canceled within 
15-30 days
 of delivery

8-14 days 
of delivery

3-7 days
 of delivery

of delivery

subject: How to welcome feedback
body:
Plus: the temptation to pay rent with a credit card. 
March 26, 2025  ·  
View in browser
 
The Insightful Leader
BY 
KELLOGG INSIGHT
Leadership advice from the Kellogg School of Management at Northwestern University
Good morning,
Any leader worth their salt is always looking for ways to improve. One way to understand where you can improve as a leader—and where your blind spots are—is to ask your team for feedback. This may seem straightforward, but getting good, actionable information requires an environment where your team feels comfortable providing candid feedback.
This week, Kellogg professor 
Leigh Thompson
 offers advice on how leaders can do just that.
How am I (really) doing?
Recently, Thompson responded to an all-too-common refrain from business leaders: they think they are encouraging open dialogue around the team’s performance and opportunities to improve their own leadership, but the feedback seems facile.
Yet many leaders “suspect that people are hesitant to share their real thoughts—perhaps out of fear of repercussions or just not wanting to rock the boat,” according to Thompson.
There are two inertias that need to be overcome in this situation.
The first consists of the leader’s own blind spots. The second is the reluctance of team members to risk offering feedback that may backfire or create tension.
 
To that end, Thompson offers tips for leaders to get the conversations going.
Start by explaining in one-on-one meetings that you are committed to improving as a leader, Thompson says. She further suggests getting specific and actionable in these one-on-ones: “Ask for their advice on specific areas, such as, ‘How can I best improve my communication, leadership, or team meetings?’ This approach lowers the perceived risk for employees and makes it easier for them to share honest insights.”
To get more frequent input, shorten the timeline for these more in-depth conversations. Rather than saddling the annual review process with the additional burden of providing 360-degree feedback, build it into a regular cadence.
“This ongoing approach normalizes feedback and makes it an integral part of your leadership journey,” Thompson says.
Read more at Thompson’s 
Dear Professor Substack
.
“If you can’t make [rent] this month, like, what’s the chance you’re not going to make it next month? And then you’re going to pay interest on that?”
— 
Lulu Wang
, on 
Marketplace
, on the temptation to pay rent with a credit card, even if it is the type that offers rewards.
See you next week,
Fred Schmalz, business and art editor
Kellogg Insight
Follow us on 
LinkedIn
.
And listen to our 
podcasts
.
Kellogg School of Management
 | 
2211 Campus Drive
, 
Evanston, IL 60208
 
Unsubscribe larry@lcwmail.com
 
Update Profile
 | 
Constant Contact Data Notice
 
Sent by 
insight@kellogg.northwestern.edu

subject: RE: Cancellations for Group M and Aflac
body:
I think Nicole should be included because she is the decision maker, no? 
 
I thought it might be useful to have a summary of GroupM’s timeline and shifts:
2/24/25: Emailed Larry first Project Assignment with start date of February 24
th
2/13: Lakisha notified us that they are not ready to start on February 24
th
 and it would “probably be the first or second week in March”. Notified Larry the same day via email
2/18:  We had an internal meeting with Group M. Lakisha said the earliest first session would be March 14
th
. Notified Larry via email. Sent Larry a revised PA with the first session being March 14
th
2/19: Received signed PA back from Larry
2/21: Larry asked me about a Spencer Stewart session. I asked Chuck about it, He confirmed that this should be added to the PA so I sent Larry a new PA which included the Spencer Stewart session on 3/6. The first GroupM session was still listed as 3/14.
3/5:  GroupM pushed back first session again and I notified Larry via email. Group I’m saying the earliest would be March 21
st
3/17: GroupM pushed back the 2025 launch again, this time to “late April at the earliest”, I notified Larry
3/25: We still don’t have a firm start date. GroupM has checked off all but one task they needed to do before we can firm up that date. We have a meeting with them tomorrow (3/16) where hopefully this last task will be resolved (it has to do with their scheduling system).
 
 
 
Rebecca M. Parrilla
 
(MBA, Latina, LGBTQ, Mom)

subject: Remote Work Is the New Labor Battlefield (Wise Decision Maker Guide 148)
body:
Wise Decision Maker Guide 
 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 
Greetings Larry,
Remote work is reshaping labor relations, with unions securing its permanence through collective bargaining. The Alphabet Workers Union (AWU) set a tech industry precedent by negotiating remote roles and workplace protections for Google Help contractors. In the public sector, the American Federation of Government Employees (AFGE) secured telework rights for Social Security Administration staff until 2029, boosting productivity amid staffing shortages. Globally, unions are addressing surveillance, work-life balance, and career equity in remote work agreements. 
These efforts signal a shift toward modernized labor activism, ensuring flexibility and protections for employees while strengthening unions' relevance in a digital workforce.
To learn more, check out this 
blog
.
Read Blog
 
Prefer video to text? See this 
video
 based on the blog:
 
If you prefer audio, listen to this 
podcast
 based on the blog:
 
Make Your Voice Heard
Vote in this 
LinkedIn poll
 to contribute to the conversation. I will use the responses to inform my articles in 
Harvard Business Review
, 
Fortune
, and 
Entrepreneur
.
 
Your Testimonials
You and others who gain value from Disaster Avoidance Experts 
services
 and thought leadership occasionally share testimonials about your experience, such as the one below. You can read more testimonials 
here
.
 
“We had the pleasure of co-hosting a webinar that was presented by Dr. Gleb. This webinar, using hybrid work to improve retention and productivity while cutting costs, was an excellent experience. He presented his research in a thoughtful and engaging way. He engaged with his attendees. He also gave them the opportunity to ask questions and give feedback at the end of the webinar. As a result, 
the survey feedback that we received following Dr. Gleb's presentation was resoundingly positive
. If you have the opportunity to work with Dr. Gleb, whether as a presenter or consultant in your organization, I highly recommend it.”
Brandie Laughner
, 
President of the Virtual Chapter of the Labor and Employment Relations Association
Schedule a Free Consultation
 
What's Up With Me
I was recently asked to be an expert witness in the killing of Amaree’ya Henderson, a Black American, by police during a routine traffic stop in Kansas City, Kansas. The police acted aggressively and escalated the situation, Henderson tried to drive away, and was then shot and killed. I was asked to explain the anxiety of Black Americans in response to discrimination and aggression by police, as well as the emotional distress experienced by his girlfriend, who was in the car with him, and his mother, who was on Facetime on the phone during the stop. 
I read the report on the incident, and then watched the
 
body cam footage
 
of the police officer doing the shooting, and my response to the body cam footage was, to me, surprisingly strong. I was already outraged by the report, but the body cam took it to another level, from intellectual, rational outrage, to something much more visceral. It gave me much more appreciation for why body cam footage needs to be made public: a picture (or video) is truly worth a thousand words, and grabs hold of you in a way that words don’t. We need to do our utmost to provide police with better training and guidance, and to incentivize municipalities to do so through legal court cases that punish police excessive use of force when police mess up. And we need to get cities to deploy body cam footage widely and release it publicly, when the family of the victim allows, to address abuses. 
Would love to get your feedback on what you found most useful about this edition of the “Wise Decision Maker Guide” - simply reply to this email.
Decisively Yours,
Dr. Gleb
 
Dr. Gleb Tsipursky
CEO of Disaster Avoidance Experts
PS: Are we connected on LinkedIn? If not, 
please add me
.

(New Harbinger, 2020)

subject: Pay Equality is Shifting – Keep Your Organization Ahead
body:
Join Trusaic for a webinar discussing pay equality laws and pay data reporting.
 
 
Dear Larry,
 
Pay equality is rapidly changing amid shifting federal mandates. Get the latest updates in Trusaic’s upcoming webinar, 
Think Pay Equality is Going Away? Think Again—Here’s What’s Nex
t. Our legal team, Maxfield Marquardt and Nasar Khan, will be joined by former OFCCP director, Craig Leen, to share regulatory updates and insights. Register today and learn how to keep your organization ahead and informed.
 
Key takeaways include:
Why state pay equality laws, transparency mandates, and pay data reporting remain in full force despite federal changes.
How pay equality audits serve as a key safeguard against pay discrimination and legal risk.
The growing risk of pay related litigation, including “reverse discrimination” lawsuits, and how organizations can mitigate exposure.
How Trusaic’s PayParity® software supports a compliant, risk-proof approach to pay equality strategy.
Register Today!
 
 
Trusaic, 520 S Grand Ave, Suite 200, Los Angeles, CA 90071, United States, 213-382-1115

subject: Don't Miss It! Coaching in Mentoring with David Clutterbuck – Live Tomorrow
body:
Don't Miss It! Coaching in Mentoring with David Clutterbuck – Live Tomorrow
 
View this email in your browser
 
 
Share
 
 
Forward
 
 
Share
 
 
Join us tomorrow, 
Wednesday, March 26 at 9am PST / 12pm EST 
for Episode 18 of our 
Thought Leader Conversation Series
Lisa Fain will be talking with 
Professor David Clutterbuck 
about 
coaching in mentoring
.
 
Register Here
 
Professor David Clutterbuck
Professor . 
Author
 . Coaching and Mentoring Innovator
David is one of the 
pioneers and foremost global authorities in Coaching and Mentoring
. He introduced supported mentoring to Europe in early 1980s and also 360-degree feedback, which he discovered in Russia whilst travelling the globe reporting on good practice in management.
An author of over 
80 books
 on coaching, mentoring, leadership and management, he also co-founded the European Mentoring & Coaching Council (he is now Special Ambassador for the EMCC) in addition to being Visiting professor, Henley Business School (Reading University) Sheffield Hallam, Oxford Brookes and York St John Universities.
A serial entrepreneur, he currently leads 
Coaching Mentoring International
 (CCMI), a global network of coaching and mentoring experts and trainers. David’s other interests include chairing the research committee of the London School of Comedy, exploring social and well-being impacts of laughter (and has trained as a stand-up comedian), lead coach for WBECS African Ethical Coaching Council, working with learning and socially disabled children and adults to promote social inclusion and is heavily involved in trying to deploy a school mentoring programme (for teachers and the kids) to schools across the World.
Outside of the office, David enjoys being a grandad and children’s author, travelling extensively (sometimes as a travel correspondent) and challenging himself to learn a new sport or activity every year.

 Monday, March 24, 2025 1:15 PM
Subject:
 Update to LCW’s Facilitator Cancellation & Postponement Policy
 
Dear LCW Consultant,
Thank you for your partnership and contributions to LCW projects—we truly appreciate your expertise and collaboration.
We want to inform you of an update you may have already noticed in your latest Project Assignment (PA) document. If you have not seen this yet, you will see it in your next PA. As a reminder, the PA document outlines the details of each project you have been contracted for with LCW.
We have made a change to our 
cancellation and postponement policy
 for trainings and facilitations. The updated terms are as follows:
If a Project Deliverable with a scheduled date is canceled or postponed: 
Within 3–5 days of delivery → LCW will pay 50% of the agreed-upon rate.
Within 2 days of delivery → LCW will pay 100% of the agreed-upon rate.
If you have any questions or need further clarification, please don’t hesitate to reach out.
We appreciate your continued collaboration and look forward to working together!
Best,
Nicole

If you have any questions or need further clarification, please don’t hesitate to reach out.
We appreciate your continued collaboration and look forward to working together!
Best,
Nicole

Subject:
 [BULK] Final Reminder: In-Person Chicagland DEI Alliance RSVP Due by 2pm!
 
 
External Sender Warning: Proceed with Caution!
You are invited to the Chicagoland DEI Alliance Q1 Member Social!
Chicagoland DEI Alliance March Member Social
 
Click here to register!
 
Registration closes TODAY in T-2.5 hours!
The Chicagoland DEI Alliance has served as a critical space for nearly 100 DEI practitioners over the last two months since we relaunched, powered by Justice Informed. From facilitating virtual discussions about the Executive Orders, to providing peer support to dozens of members navigating the legal and political environment while holding the line for the power of DEI, to creating a brave space for practitioners to open up and support one another during this challenging time...the DEI Alliance has been full of energy and opportunity for those members who have tapped in to the space. We've had CDOs from major universities and Fortune 500s, executive directors of social impact focused nonprofits, consultants, and more all join this community.  Members have received tactical support and advice to navaigate their company or nonprofit's challenges, gotten weekly updates on the state of DEI at the national and local level, and enjoyed space to brainstorm about how the Alliance can be a powerful example for the state and nation as a model of collective action and workplace practitioner support. 
 
Now we are ready for our first in-person event! You received an email about this a while back, and this is our final invitation: You are invited! We would LOVE to see you! We alrady have several dozen DEI leaders from across Chicagoland who have committed to attending. Meet the new leadership team, learn about what we have planned, and enjoy some light bites and drinks on the house. 
 
Date: Tuesday, March 25th from 4-6pm CST
Location: Impact House/FBRK (200 W Madison Street, Chicago, IL, 2nd floor)
 
Day of Contact: Xavier Ramey, Lead Strategist for the Chicagoland DEI Alliance and CEO, Justice Informed. 
xavier@justiceinformed.com
 or 312-523-3705
General event info: Contact Anna Radoff, Head of Impact, Justice Informed, 
anna@justiceinformed.com
 
This event will be an in-person event for the Chicagoland DEI Alliance. 
 
Space logistics:
Impact House, 200 W Madison, Floor 2
Please note that this is a coworking space for multiple social impact organizations. We will be in the large bar and social area on the second floor.
Limited street parking is available along Wells or Franklin Streets, and a covered parking lot is available for attendees across the street (Poetry Garage) or via public transit.
Security: Please bring a photo ID, and let them know you are here to visit Impact House/Xavier Ramey on the second floor. All registered guests who RSVP via eventbrite will be added to the security list. If you do not RSVP, you will need to email Anna Radoff or Xavier Ramey to get access on the day-of the event. For registered guests, you will be provided a pass to the elevators, and you can then come up to the second floor. If you have an issue, please contact Xavier at 312-523-3705. 
Accessibility: The building has ADA-compliant, fully accessible entrances and elevators, as well as restroom facilities. 
All attendees must be registered.
 
See you soon! Click the link below to register, or email Anna or Xavier with any questions you have. 
 
 
Click here to register!
 
 
Chicagoland DEI Alliance powered by Justice Informed, 1074 W Taylor St, Chicago, IL 60607

subject: Don’t Miss Ep. 18 of Thought Leader Conversations with Professor David Clutterbuck – Tomorrow!
body:
Don’t Miss Ep. 18 of Thought Leader Conversations with Professor David Clutterbuck – Tomorrow!
 
View this email in your browser
 
 
Share
 
 
Forward
 
 
Share
 
 
Join us tomorrow, 
Wednesday, March 26th at 9am PST / 12pm EST / 5pm GMT 
for Episode 18 of our 
Thought Leader Conversation Series
Lisa Fain will be talking with 
Professor David Clutterbuck 
about 
coaching in mentoring
.
 
Register Here
 
Professor David Clutterbuck
Professor, Author, Coaching Innovator
David is one of the pioneers and foremost global authorities in Coaching and Mentoring. He introduced supported mentoring to Europe in early 1980s and also 360-degree feedback, which he discovered in Russia whilst travelling the globe reporting on good practice in management.
An author of over 80 books on coaching, mentoring, leadership and management, he also co-founded the European Mentoring & Coaching Council (he is now Special Ambassador for the EMCC) in addition to being Visiting professor, Henley Business School (Reading University) Sheffield Hallam, Oxford Brookes and York St John Universities.
A serial entrepreneur, he currently leads 
Coaching Mentoring International
 (CCMI), a global network of coaching and mentoring experts and trainers. David’s other interests include chairing the research committee of the London School of Comedy, exploring social and well-being impacts of laughter (and has trained as a stand-up comedian), lead coach for WBECS African Ethical Coaching Council, working with learning and socially disabled children and adults to promote social inclusion and is heavily involved in trying to deploy a school mentoring programme (for teachers and the kids) to schools across the World.
Outside of the office, David enjoys being a grandad and children’s author, travelling extensively (sometimes as a travel correspondent) and challenging himself to learn a new sport or activity every year.
 
 
 
Click Here to Catch up on Past Conversations

subject: Neuroinclusion tips & cognitive accessibility
body:
Resources for you! 
͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌  
 
formerly Texthelp
March 2025 
Larry Your monthly roundup of tips, tricks, resources & more!  
Changing the narrative on neurodiversity
 
Over the last week people and businesses around the world have been getting involved in Neurodiversity Celebration Week - a worldwide initiative that challenges stereotypes about neurological differences. 
The week may be over but the mission to change the narrative is not. 
Here’s some resources to help you challenge stigma in your own organization - feel free to share them with your colleagues!
 
 
Combat stigma
 
Our Founder shares
 four ways employers can combat stigmas surrounding neurodiversity
 
 
Grow understanding
 
Our neurodivergent friend Cory shares 
six facts he wishes people understood about neurodiversity
 
 
Celebrate difference
 
Four neurodivergent individuals share the talents they bring to the workplace
 
 
Take action
 
Nine experts from leading brands share their insights to help you advance neuroinclusion
Coming up this week…
 
On Thursday, three global brands will join us to share the neuroinclusive strategies helping them to unlock the potential of all employees. Join us and gain strategies to bring back to your own organization.
Sign up now 
Neurodiversity & web accessibility… 
Creating accessible websites means recognizing how different people process information - and understanding how design can make information processing easier. 
For example people with Autism benefit from predictable patterns. Those with ADHD benefit from clear, structured layouts. 
Here, the A11y Collective shares best practices for cognitive accessibility
. The tips they share benefit not only those with neurological differences - but everyone! 
 
Championing cognitive accessibility with ReachDeck
 
Our digital inclusion tool, ReachDeck, helps to make websites easier to access and understand. With the ReachDeck Auditor, find accessibility and readability errors at scale. With the ReachDeck Editor, write content that’s easier for everyone to understand. 
Discover more
.
 
Behind the scenes at Everway
 
Over the past couple of weeks our Everway teams from across the globe have been getting together to connect, share ideas, and shape the future of our new brand. From Atlanta to London, 
here’s a behind-the-scenes look at some of the best moments from our all-company meetings
. 
 
We want to hear from you 
We want to give you content that you find useful. So, we'd love to hear from you. What topics would you love to see featured in this newsletter? Or do you have a good neuroinclusion story to tell? Your input will help us to bring you valuable content in return. 
 
Reach out to 
abby@texthelp.com
 and let us know!  
Kind regards, 
The Everway team 
formerly Texthelp

Subject:
 [BULK] Final Reminder: In-Person Chicagland DEI Alliance RSVP Due by 2pm!
 
 
External Sender Warning: Proceed with Caution!
You are invited to the Chicagoland DEI Alliance Q1 Member Social!
Chicagoland DEI Alliance March Member Social
 
Click here to register!
 
Registration closes TODAY in T-2.5 hours!
The Chicagoland DEI Alliance has served as a critical space for nearly 100 DEI practitioners over the last two months since we relaunched, powered by Justice Informed. From facilitating virtual discussions about the Executive Orders, to providing peer support to dozens of members navigating the legal and political environment while holding the line for the power of DEI, to creating a brave space for practitioners to open up and support one another during this challenging time...the DEI Alliance has been full of energy and opportunity for those members who have tapped in to the space. We've had CDOs from major universities and Fortune 500s, executive directors of social impact focused nonprofits, consultants, and more all join this community.  Members have received tactical support and advice to navaigate their company or nonprofit's challenges, gotten weekly updates on the state of DEI at the national and local level, and enjoyed space to brainstorm about how the Alliance can be a powerful example for the state and nation as a model of collective action and workplace practitioner support. 
 
Now we are ready for our first in-person event! You received an email about this a while back, and this is our final invitation: You are invited! We would LOVE to see you! We alrady have several dozen DEI leaders from across Chicagoland who have committed to attending. Meet the new leadership team, learn about what we have planned, and enjoy some light bites and drinks on the house. 
 
Date: Tuesday, March 25th from 4-6pm CST
Location: Impact House/FBRK (200 W Madison Street, Chicago, IL, 2nd floor)
 
Day of Contact: Xavier Ramey, Lead Strategist for the Chicagoland DEI Alliance and CEO, Justice Informed. 
xavier@justiceinformed.com
 or 312-523-3705
General event info: Contact Anna Radoff, Head of Impact, Justice Informed, 
anna@justiceinformed.com
 
This event will be an in-person event for the Chicagoland DEI Alliance. 
 
Space logistics:
Impact House, 200 W Madison, Floor 2
Please note that this is a coworking space for multiple social impact organizations. We will be in the large bar and social area on the second floor.
Limited street parking is available along Wells or Franklin Streets, and a covered parking lot is available for attendees across the street (Poetry Garage) or via public transit.
Security: Please bring a photo ID, and let them know you are here to visit Impact House/Xavier Ramey on the second floor. All registered guests who RSVP via eventbrite will be added to the security list. If you do not RSVP, you will need to email Anna Radoff or Xavier Ramey to get access on the day-of the event. For registered guests, you will be provided a pass to the elevators, and you can then come up to the second floor. If you have an issue, please contact Xavier at 312-523-3705. 
Accessibility: The building has ADA-compliant, fully accessible entrances and elevators, as well as restroom facilities. 
All attendees must be registered.
 
See you soon! Click the link below to register, or email Anna or Xavier with any questions you have. 
 
 
Click here to register!
 
 
Chicagoland DEI Alliance powered by Justice Informed, 1074 W Taylor St, Chicago, IL 60607

You are invited to the Chicagoland DEI Alliance Q1 Member Social!
Chicagoland DEI Alliance March Member Social
 
Click here to register!
 
Registration closes TODAY in T-2.5 hours!
The Chicagoland DEI Alliance has served as a critical space for nearly 100 DEI practitioners over the last two months since we relaunched, powered by Justice Informed. From facilitating virtual discussions about the Executive Orders, to providing peer support to dozens of members navigating the legal and political environment while holding the line for the power of DEI, to creating a brave space for practitioners to open up and support one another during this challenging time...the DEI Alliance has been full of energy and opportunity for those members who have tapped in to the space. We've had CDOs from major universities and Fortune 500s, executive directors of social impact focused nonprofits, consultants, and more all join this community.  Members have received tactical support and advice to navaigate their company or nonprofit's challenges, gotten weekly updates on the state of DEI at the national and local level, and enjoyed space to brainstorm about how the Alliance can be a powerful example for the state and nation as a model of collective action and workplace practitioner support. 
 
Now we are ready for our first in-person event! You received an email about this a while back, and this is our final invitation: You are invited! We would LOVE to see you! We alrady have several dozen DEI leaders from across Chicagoland who have committed to attending. Meet the new leadership team, learn about what we have planned, and enjoy some light bites and drinks on the house. 
 
Date: Tuesday, March 25th from 4-6pm CST
Location: Impact House/FBRK (200 W Madison Street, Chicago, IL, 2nd floor)
