subject: 👗 👔 Culturally Inclusive Dress Codes: Challenging the Conventional Notion of “Professional Image”
body:
Continue reading to learn how to create a culturally inclusive dress code for your organization. ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Hello Larry!
 
Could your dress code be silently excluding people? 
 
🛑
 
Picture this
Imagine walking into your office and realizing that the very policies meant to reflect professionalism are making some of your most talented employees feel like outsiders. They hesitate at the closet each morning, wondering: 
“Will what I wear today be considered ‘professional’ enough—or too different to be accepted?”
 
Your organization may pride itself on being inclusive—but if the dress code only reflects one cultural norm, it may be unintentionally silencing others. 
 
🥻
 
The Experience
For an Indian woman, a sari is not just an attire—it’s heritage. For a Muslim man, wearing a thobe is a symbol of faith and identity. Yet, in many workplaces, these expressions of culture are quietly discouraged in favor of Western-style suits and skirts. 
Employees begin to self-censor. They conform—not because they want to—but because they feel they have to. And in doing so, they leave a part of themselves at the door. 
 
⚠️
 
The Problem
When your dress code reinforces a narrow idea of what “professional” looks like, it doesn’t just limit wardrobe choices—it limits belonging. 
This seemingly minor policy issue becomes a major roadblock to inclusion. Employees feel unseen, undervalued, and disconnected. For team leaders, it becomes a source of friction, pushback, and quiet disengagement that erodes culture from within. 
 
💡
 
The Future You’re Waiting For
Now picture this: Your employees walk through the door proud of who they are—and how they show up. Their attire reflects their culture, their values, and their full selves. 
Your dress code doesn’t dilute professionalism—it expands it. And your organization becomes known not just for hiring diverse talent, but for keeping it. 
This is the kind of culture where 
everyone feels like they truly belong
. A culture that thrives on authenticity—not uniformity. 
 
🎤
 
What’s Next
In Part 2 of this series, coming later this week, I’ll share 
practical, actionable strategies
 to help you evolve your dress code policies in ways that are inclusive, respectful, and still aligned with your organization’s standards. 
Let’s move beyond outdated norms and create policies that actually reflect the diverse people who make your workplace great. 
 
👉
 Stay tuned—change is on the way.
 
Bye for now, 
 
Luiza
___________________________________
 
Luiza Dreasher, Founder and CEO (she/her/hers)
Mastering Cultural Differences 
I work with leaders who want to create a work environment where all employees feel valued and want to stay.
At 
Mastering Cultural Differences LLC,
 we are committed to helping organizations build inclusive, culturally competent workplaces where every individual feels valued and respected. Through highly customized programs, we equip teams with knowledge and skills to help them connect and collaborate more effectively across differences. subject: Equal Pay Day today - the current state of the gender pay gap for women
body:
📅 
Happenings
APRIL FREE WEBINAR
 -
 
Join us for a free open webinar with special guests. 
90 Days In: Reigniting Actionable Allyship in a Defining Moment 
takes place on 
Apr. 23rd at 1pm ET.
 Join Julie Kratz, Dr. Akilah Cadet, and Karen Catlin for a conversation tackling tough but necessary conversations on allyship, action, and accountability. Learn how to move beyond performative gestures, re-engage meaningfully, and navigate discomfort in today’s political and social climate. Whether you’re setting boundaries, or taking your activism further, this session is for you. 
Register for free here
.
April Webinar Details
INTERNATIONAL ALLYSHIP DAY
 - Join us in NYC or virtually on August 8th for our 
2nd annual International Allyship Day event
, hosted by our partner AllianceBernstein. This year’s focus is on equipping inclusion and ERG leaders with actionable strategies to strengthen or launch allyship programs within their organizations. Participants will gain essential skills for effective allyship, pushback-proof strategies, and insights into the strategic business impact of allyship. They’ll also have the chance to connect with senior leaders in the inclusion space. We're consistently adding exciting new speakers and organizations like Coqual and Dr. Sandra Upton - 
will your organization be there?
 
Register individually or as a team here
.
​
 
​
📝 Equal Pay Day
In honor of Equal Pay Day today March 25th, I've moved my weekly newsletter to Tuesday for this week. This awareness day each year is always striking to me and it feels especially important to share and encourage awareness in these uncertain times when women and marginalized groups are feeling more and more attacked.
If you're new to this awareness event, Equal Pay Day marks the current state of the gender pay gap for women: 83% for full-time, year-round workers and 75% for all workers (including part-time and seasonal). This day was originated by the National Committee on Pay Equity (NCPE) in 1996 as a public awareness event to illustrate the gap between men’s and women’s wages. 
This date symbolizes how many days women must work to earn what men earned in the previous year.
 It's also critical to note that the pay gap varies significantly among different communities, particularly for women of color - see the 
full calendar
 reported below:
All Women’s Equal Pay Day – March 25th
Asian American, Native Hawaiian and Pacific Islander (AANHPI) Women’s Equal Pay Day – April 7th
Moms’ Equal Pay Day – May 6th
LGBTQIA+ Equal Pay Awareness Day – June 17th
Black Women’s Equal Pay Day – July 10th
Native Hawaiian and Pacific Islander (NHPI) Women’s Equal Pay Day – August 28th
Latina Equal Pay Day – October 8th
Disabled Women’s Equal Pay Day – October 23rd
Native Women’s Equal Pay Day – November 18th
To be a part of the solution vs. the problem, allies advocate for equal pay because it is important that everyone is paid fairly. This is not just good for women, it is also good for all genders. Financial stress is the single biggest issue households face. The gender pay gap can negatively affect men by causing increased stress and tension within the family. This is due to the fact that men may need to work longer hours to make up for the lower earnings of women or take on the role of the primary earner when unprepared. Ultimately, the unfair pay hurts the well-being of the entire household. 
Read more about why it matters and what you can do here
 
- be sure to share with your teams.
Thanks allies,
Julie
​
💬 
Allyship Conversation Starters & Resources
​
Employees care less and less about workplace relationships, new research finds
 - insights from Adam Grant
​
​
 
​
DEI could get better than ever
 
- 
The intense pressure to end diversity initiatives has led companies to scrutinize their policies. Many will end up making them stronger 💪
​
 
Care about inclusion for the little ones in your life? Check out the programs and resources from 
LITTLE ALLIES
, a nonprofit working to facilitate inclusive experiences for all children to feel seen, heard, and belong.
​
Next Pivot Point
 
works to promote allyship and inclusion across all dimensions of diversity in the workplace to make sure everyone feels seen, heard, and belonging at work.
​
Next Pivot Point
​

MEMBER NEWS
New Pathways & Possibilities in Hospitality Education
PRESENTED BY NATIONAL LOUIS UNIVERSITY
 
The future of hospitality education is evolving, with new models emerging to address workforce challenges and bridge the gap between students and employers. Join industry leaders for a dynamic discussion on innovative training approaches, including apprenticeships, vocational programs, and collaborative efforts between government, nonprofits, and colleges. Chicagoland Chamber Board Chair Dan Lynch will be among the featured speakers, sharing insights on how these evolving pathways can create a more prepared and motivated hospitality workforce. Don’t miss this opportunity to explore the future of talent development and connect with key stakeholders shaping the industry’s next chapter.
REGISTER NOW
 
MEMBER NEWS
Breaking Barriers: Transforming Women’s Health Luncheon 
PRESENTED BY THE AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY
 
Join the American Cancer Society on Wednesday, April 30 for the Breaking Barriers: Transforming Women's Health Luncheon, benefitting the ResearcHERS movement, which funds women-led cancer research and addresses the underrepresentation of women in leadership roles. Spend the afternoon networking with peers and hearing from a distinguished panel of experts on critical women’s wellness issues, cancer risk factors, and the physical, mental, and financial challenges many women face. Discover how these factors impact health outcomes and cancer risks and learn about the efforts being made to improve women’s health nationwide.
REGISTER NOW
 
UPCOMING EVENT
AI in Action: Solving Real Business Challenges
PRESENTED BY THE CHICAGOLAND CHAMBER OF COMMERCE
 
Discover how AI can address real challenges within your organization in this interactive workshop. We’ll begin with an overview of cutting-edge AI tools and real-world applications, showcasing how businesses are leveraging AI for success. Then, in small breakout groups, you’ll collaborate to develop practical AI use cases tailored to your organization’s needs. Walk away with actionable insights and strategies to implement AI-driven solutions effectively. Register by April 15 to receive an early-bird rate.
REGISTER NOW
 
Want to showcase your company news, information, products, or services?
 
Chamber members are able to take advantage of a myriad of benefits to help your business grow, including inclusion in this email newsletter. With a broad distribution, you can gain access to a new audience that you may not otherwise be able to reach.
REVIEW BENEFITS
 
 
FOLLOW THE CHAMBER
 
 
 
 
 
WWW.CHICAGOLANDCHAMBER.ORG
The Chicagoland Chamber of Commerce
The Wrigley Building | 410 N Michigan Ave | Suite 900
Chicago, IL 60611
 
Change Your Subscription Preferences
 at any time.

Privacy Policy
.

subject: Re: Update to LCW’s Facilitator Cancellation & Postponement Policy
body:
That's fine and good. However, it appears that from Nicole's email that if dates that I had been expecting to be paid for get moved, I'm still owed some money. Am I reading this wrong?
Sent via the Samsung Galaxy S22+ 5G, an AT&T 5G smartphone

From:

Sent:
 Monday, March 24, 2025 2:09:51 PM
To:
 Larry Baker <l.baker@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 RE: Update to LCW’s Facilitator Cancellation & Postponement Policy
 
 
Hey, LBJ! Why don’t I send you a new PA with the new dates as soon as we get them nailed down with GroupM. The good news is, they are postponing and not cancelling. I met with them today and things are advancing, the content is now 100% final and the comms are final. There’s still one smallish technical thing to work out with respect to their internal scheduling system, but it appears we’re very close to setting the launch date!! 
 
Rebecca M. Parrilla

Sent:
 Monday, March 24, 2025 1:15 PM
Subject:
 Update to LCW’s Facilitator Cancellation & Postponement Policy
 
Dear LCW Consultant,
Thank you for your partnership and contributions to LCW projects—we truly appreciate your expertise and collaboration.
We want to inform you of an update you may have already noticed in your latest Project Assignment (PA) document. If you have not seen this yet, you will see it in your next PA. As a reminder, the PA document outlines the details of each project you have been contracted for with LCW.
We have made a change to our 
cancellation and postponement policy
 for trainings and facilitations. The updated terms are as follows:
If a 
Project Deliverable
 with a scheduled date is 
canceled or postponed
: 
Within 3–5 days of delivery
 → LCW will pay 
50%
 of the agreed-upon rate.
Within 2 days of delivery
 → LCW will pay 
100%
 of the agreed-upon rate.
If you have any questions or need further clarification, please don’t hesitate to reach out.
We appreciate your continued collaboration and look forward to working together!
Best,
Nicole
 
Nicole Barile
 
(She/Her)
Chief Operating Officer
LCW

Subject:
 [BULK] Final Reminder: In-Person Chicagland DEI Alliance RSVP Due by 2pm!
 
 
External Sender Warning: Proceed with Caution!
You are invited to the Chicagoland DEI Alliance Q1 Member Social!
Chicagoland DEI Alliance March Member Social
 
Click here to register!
 
Registration closes TODAY in T-2.5 hours!
The Chicagoland DEI Alliance has served as a critical space for nearly 100 DEI practitioners over the last two months since we relaunched, powered by Justice Informed. From facilitating virtual discussions about the Executive Orders, to providing peer support to dozens of members navigating the legal and political environment while holding the line for the power of DEI, to creating a brave space for practitioners to open up and support one another during this challenging time...the DEI Alliance has been full of energy and opportunity for those members who have tapped in to the space. We've had CDOs from major universities and Fortune 500s, executive directors of social impact focused nonprofits, consultants, and more all join this community.  Members have received tactical support and advice to navaigate their company or nonprofit's challenges, gotten weekly updates on the state of DEI at the national and local level, and enjoyed space to brainstorm about how the Alliance can be a powerful example for the state and nation as a model of collective action and workplace practitioner support. 
 
Now we are ready for our first in-person event! You received an email about this a while back, and this is our final invitation: You are invited! We would LOVE to see you! We alrady have several dozen DEI leaders from across Chicagoland who have committed to attending. Meet the new leadership team, learn about what we have planned, and enjoy some light bites and drinks on the house. 
 
Date: Tuesday, March 25th from 4-6pm CST
Location: Impact House/FBRK (200 W Madison Street, Chicago, IL, 2nd floor)
 
Day of Contact: Xavier Ramey, Lead Strategist for the Chicagoland DEI Alliance and CEO, Justice Informed. 
xavier@justiceinformed.com
 or 312-523-3705
General event info: Contact Anna Radoff, Head of Impact, Justice Informed, 
anna@justiceinformed.com
 
This event will be an in-person event for the Chicagoland DEI Alliance. 
 
Space logistics:
Impact House, 200 W Madison, Floor 2
Please note that this is a coworking space for multiple social impact organizations. We will be in the large bar and social area on the second floor.
Limited street parking is available along Wells or Franklin Streets, and a covered parking lot is available for attendees across the street (Poetry Garage) or via public transit.
Security: Please bring a photo ID, and let them know you are here to visit Impact House/Xavier Ramey on the second floor. All registered guests who RSVP via eventbrite will be added to the security list. If you do not RSVP, you will need to email Anna Radoff or Xavier Ramey to get access on the day-of the event. For registered guests, you will be provided a pass to the elevators, and you can then come up to the second floor. If you have an issue, please contact Xavier at 312-523-3705. 
Accessibility: The building has ADA-compliant, fully accessible entrances and elevators, as well as restroom facilities. 
All attendees must be registered.
 
See you soon! Click the link below to register, or email Anna or Xavier with any questions you have. 
 
 
Click here to register!
 
 
Chicagoland DEI Alliance powered by Justice Informed, 1074 W Taylor St, Chicago, IL 60607

You are invited to the Chicagoland DEI Alliance Q1 Member Social!
Chicagoland DEI Alliance March Member Social
 
Click here to register!
 
Registration closes TODAY in T-2.5 hours!
The Chicagoland DEI Alliance has served as a critical space for nearly 100 DEI practitioners over the last two months since we relaunched, powered by Justice Informed. From facilitating virtual discussions about the Executive Orders, to providing peer support to dozens of members navigating the legal and political environment while holding the line for the power of DEI, to creating a brave space for practitioners to open up and support one another during this challenging time...the DEI Alliance has been full of energy and opportunity for those members who have tapped in to the space. We've had CDOs from major universities and Fortune 500s, executive directors of social impact focused nonprofits, consultants, and more all join this community.  Members have received tactical support and advice to navaigate their company or nonprofit's challenges, gotten weekly updates on the state of DEI at the national and local level, and enjoyed space to brainstorm about how the Alliance can be a powerful example for the state and nation as a model of collective action and workplace practitioner support. 
 
Now we are ready for our first in-person event! You received an email about this a while back, and this is our final invitation: You are invited! We would LOVE to see you! We alrady have several dozen DEI leaders from across Chicagoland who have committed to attending. Meet the new leadership team, learn about what we have planned, and enjoy some light bites and drinks on the house. 
 
Date: Tuesday, March 25th from 4-6pm CST
Location: Impact House/FBRK (200 W Madison Street, Chicago, IL, 2nd floor)
 
Day of Contact: Xavier Ramey, Lead Strategist for the Chicagoland DEI Alliance and CEO, Justice Informed. xavier@justiceinformed.com or 312-523-3705
General event info: Contact Anna Radoff, Head of Impact, Justice Informed, anna@justiceinformed.com
 
This event will be an in-person event for the Chicagoland DEI Alliance. 
 
Space logistics:
Impact House, 200 W Madison, Floor 2
Please note that this is a coworking space for multiple social impact organizations. We will be in the large bar and social area on the second floor.
Limited street parking is available along Wells or Franklin Streets, and a covered parking lot is available for attendees across the street (Poetry Garage) or via public transit.
Security: Please bring a photo ID, and let them know you are here to visit Impact House/Xavier Ramey on the second floor. All registered guests who RSVP via eventbrite will be added to the security list. If you do not RSVP, you will need to email Anna Radoff or Xavier Ramey to get access on the day-of the event. For registered guests, you will be provided a pass to the elevators, and you can then come up to the second floor. If you have an issue, please contact Xavier at 312-523-3705.

We have made a change to our 
cancellation and postponement policy

If a 
Project Deliverable

canceled or postponed

50%

 → LCW will pay 
100%
 of the agreed-upon rate.

subject: FW: notes
body:
From:
 Larry Baker 
Sent:
 Friday, January 31, 2025 2:21 PM
To:
 Larry Baker <lbjbaker1@gmail.com>
Subject:
 notes
 
A 
skill-based approach
 to building a workplace has several 
benefits
 but also comes with 
risks
 that organizations must carefully manage.
✅
 Benefits of a Skill-Based Workplace
1. Expands the Talent Pool
Hiring based on skills (rather than degrees or past job titles) opens opportunities to a wider, more diverse group of candidates.
Helps address labor shortages by recognizing non-traditional career paths and alternative learning (e.g., boot camps, certifications).
2. Promotes Internal Mobility & Retention
Employees can 
move laterally or upward
 within the company based on demonstrated skills.
Reduces turnover by giving employees career development opportunities without forcing them to leave for promotions elsewhere.
3. Encourages Continuous Learning & Innovation
A culture of upskilling and reskilling keeps the workforce adaptable to industry changes.
Encourages employees to take ownership of their growth, making the company more innovative.
4. Improves Workforce Agility & Resilience
Organizations can quickly 
redeploy
 employees into new roles as business needs shift.
More flexibility in assembling 
cross-functional teams
 based on skill sets rather than rigid job descriptions.
5. Creates a More Inclusive and Equitable Workplace
Reduces bias in hiring by focusing on 
what candidates can do
 rather than their backgrounds.
Increases diversity by valuing skills gained through alternative education, self-learning, or experience outside of traditional career paths.
6. Aligns Performance & Compensation with Real Value
Pay and promotions are tied to 
actual skills and contributions
, not just tenure.
Encourages a 
meritocratic environment
 where employees advance based on competency rather than internal politics.
⚠️
 Risks and Challenges of a Skill-Based Workplace
1. Difficult to Implement Without Strong Systems
Requires 
robust assessment methods
 to accurately measure skills (e.g., competency tests, project-based evaluations).
Traditional HR structures (e.g., job descriptions, performance reviews) may need 
significant restructuring
.
2. Potential for Bias in Skill Assessments
If assessments aren’t well-designed, bias can creep in, 
favoring certain groups
 based on how skills are evaluated.
Soft skills (e.g., leadership, communication) are harder to quantify, leading to 
subjective judgments
.
3. Resistance from Leadership & Employees
Leaders accustomed to 
credential-based hiring
 may be skeptical about hiring/promoting based on skills alone.
Employees may feel uncertain about career paths if 
traditional job titles and hierarchies
 are de-emphasized.
4. Can Overlook the Value of Experience
Experience often provides 
context, judgment, and industry knowledge
 that raw skills alone don’t cover.
New hires with the right skills but 
little industry exposure
 might struggle with workplace dynamics or strategic thinking.
5. Requires Constant Investment in Upskilling & Reskilling
Companies must provide 
ongoing learning opportunities
 to keep skills relevant.
Without a clear 
learning & development (L&D) strategy
, employees may feel unsupported or left behind.
6. Job Role Clarity Can Become Blurred
Employees may 
juggle multiple responsibilities
 based on their skill sets, leading to 
role confusion
.
Career progression paths may feel less structured, making it harder for employees to see their next steps.
🔍
 How to Maximize the Benefits While Managing Risks
✅
 
Use a mix of skills and experience
 → Prioritize skills but also recognize the value of experience and institutional knowledge.
✅
 
Invest in strong skill assessments
 → Develop fair, objective ways to evaluate both 
hard
 and 
soft
 skills (e.g., work samples, structured interviews).
✅
 
Ensure leadership buy-in
 → Train managers on how to 
assess, develop, and reward skills
 instead of relying on traditional career markers.
✅
 
Create clear career pathways
 → Offer structured 
upskilling programs
 and transparent growth opportunities so employees understand how to advance.
✅
 
Foster a learning culture
 → Make continuous learning a core part of the workplace, providing employees with the tools to 
develop and showcase
 new skills.
A skill-based approach 
can future-proof a workplace
 if implemented thoughtfully. However, companies must navigate challenges carefully to avoid bias, role confusion, and resistance to change. Would you like guidance on how to apply this approach to a specific company or industry?
 
 
Taking a 
skill-based approach
 to building your workplace means prioritizing skills over traditional factors like job titles, degrees, or years of experience when hiring, developing, and promoting employees. Instead of focusing solely on credentials, organizations identify, assess, and cultivate the specific skills employees need to succeed in their roles.
Key Aspects of a Skill-Based Workplace:
Hiring Based on Skills, Not Just Credentials
Job descriptions focus on required skills rather than degree requirements or past job titles.
Candidates are assessed through practical tests, case studies, or work samples instead of just resumes.
This approach widens the talent pool, allowing for more diverse and capable hires.
Internal Mobility and Career Growth
Employees can move between roles based on their skills, not just their formal job history.
Skill assessments help identify employees ready for new challenges, even in different departments.
Companies offer 
upskilling
 and 
reskilling
 programs to help employees grow.
Continuous Learning and Development
Training programs focus on enhancing employees' technical and soft skills.
Microlearning, mentorship, and on-the-job experiences are prioritized over one-time training.
Employees are encouraged to gain certifications or participate in skills workshops.
Performance and Compensation Based on Skills
Raises and promotions are linked to skill mastery rather than tenure.
Employees are evaluated based on their ability to perform key tasks and take on more responsibility.
Building a More Agile and Inclusive Workforce
Organizations can adapt faster to industry changes by developing in-demand skills.
Employees with non-traditional backgrounds get opportunities based on demonstrated ability.
Encourages a more 
collaborative and innovation-driven
 culture.
Example of a Skill-Based Approach in Action:
A company needs to fill a 
Project Manager
 role. Instead of requiring 5+ years in project management and a formal degree, they assess candidates on their ability to:
✔️
 Organize tasks and timelines
✔️
 Communicate effectively with stakeholders
✔️
 Use project management software
✔️
 Solve problems and adapt to challenges
They hire an internal candidate from customer service who has demonstrated these skills in their role and provide additional training to fill any gaps.
Why This Matters:
A skill-based approach 
future-proofs
 the workplace by ensuring employees can adapt to changing job requirements. It also fosters 
equity, efficiency, and innovation
—creating a work environment where people are valued for what they can do, not just their background.
Would you like insights on how to implement this approach in a specific workplace setting?

subject: - Why do I do what I do?
body:
Spoiler: It's corny. And authentic.‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­
 
 
A little context about some big news...
Way, way back in high school when I got the “What do you want to be when you grow up?” question, I recall answering, “I don’t know yet but farther down the road I could see myself teaching.” All I really knew was that I wanted to make a difference in people’s lives. And a positive one at that.
 
I knew classroom teaching wasn’t my sweet spot, but I dabbled in it on three continents before I found my way to transformational training and facilitation for adults, and a few years later when I became MBTI and coaching certification Sparks of Change was born. I’ve long known I am not the one to lead the movement, but my role is to support and spark, if you will, others to be and do their best. And, in the past two years a new identity emerged as I became a trauma-informed coach and healer, developing myself into a somatic and spiritual leader.
As coach, facilitator, trainer, instructional designer and healer—my role is to help people get along just a little better. Corny factor acknowledged, this is my bit towards world peace. 
Psst:
­
Read the gory details of my journey summarized in pithy bullet points.
­
About Me
 
Last summer I started itching to figure out how to communicate the common thread to my roles and skills.  
Thus, with help from the amazing folks at 
Perspektiiv
, 
I am thrilled to launch the new Sparks of Change website!
­
Check it out now! 
 
­
I facilitate connection
 to yourself, to others and with Spirit.  
I take a holistic and inclusive approach to wellness, experiential learning and facilitation for individuals and groups interested in transformation and wellbeing. 
Promo code: CONNECTION
To celebrate and be of service to those who know me and those will be new,  I am gifting everyone a deep discount to come work with me. 
 
Use code CONNECTION for a 25% discount on any offering. Must be purchased by April 15, 2025 but you can schedule sessions for any time, they won't expire.
 
This is heart work, I offer a money back guarantee if you are not satisfied. 
 
Let's Connect Now
­
I would love to support and learn along with you, 
 
Joayne Nicole 
­
Sparks of Change
4509 Oakland Ave, 55407, Minneapolis

subject: Join us to send a powerful message. We will stand strong.
body:
This is not just a summit; it’s a call to action, a gathering of passionate minds committed to creating a future of inclusion.
 
Join us to send a powerful message. 
We will stand strong. 
We will continue to advocate for the rights of all people to thrive in the workplace and the world. We will come together, in community, to support each other to navigate and prevail through these volatile times.
 
The fight for diversity, equity, and inclusion isn’t over — it’s evolving. The 
2025 Justice for All Summit: The Power of Inclusion
 isn’t just another event; it’s a gathering of changemakers, trailblazers, and leaders ready to set the record straight and reclaim the power of inclusion in our new reality.
 
Now is the time to stand together, to make our voices louder than the opposition, to show the world that we’re not giving up, and to:
Find your people.
 Expand your network with those who share your passion and purpose.
Set the record straight.
 Equip yourself with the insights and strategies to push back against misinformation.
Fuel progress.
 Harness the power of inclusion to drive meaningful impact in your industry and beyond.
Let’s turn momentum into action. We'll see you there.
Register for the 2025 Justice for All Summit
 
 
Register for the 2025 Justice for All Summit
 
 
What to Expect at This Event:
50+ dynamic speakers
 and 
6 keynote sessions
 featuring leading experts and changemakers
Engaging sessions on 
Inclusive Leadership
, 
Psychological Safety
, 
Neurodiversity
, 
Allyship
, 
Tech and AI
, 
Burnout
, and much more
Networking opportunities
 to connect with like-minded professionals
Performing artists
 and wellness corners to rejuvenate your spirit
This summit is your chance to deepen your knowledge, build actionable strategies, and leave with tools to create meaningful, lasting change in your organization.
Register for the 2025 Justice for All Summit
 
 
The 2024 Racial Justice at Work Summit: Justice for All won the Gold Stevie® Award for Event of the Year!
More than 1,500 entries from organizations and individuals in 36 nations and territories were submitted this year for consideration in more than 100 categories. We are proud to be recognized and can't wait to continue the momentum April 21-24, 2025.
 
We need to stand united in our support of diversity, equity, and inclusion — and each other. The transformation starts here with your commitment and support.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
The Winters Group, 8116 South Tryon Street, Ste. B3-260, Charlotte, North Carolina 28273, United States

Say Goodbye to No-Shows
Reducing no-shows is simpler than you think. 
Upgrade
 and help everyone show up on time and prepared:
Set clear expectations.
 Share an agenda ahead of time to help invitees prepare and show up ready to engage.
Automate reminders.
 Save time by scheduling email and text reminders with personalized messages tailored to your meeting.
Ask for reconfirmation.
 Automate an email or text asking your invitees to reconfirm the scheduled time - especially helpful if you charge for your time or have a strict cancellation policy.
Simplify rescheduling.
 Life happens — make it easy for invitees to reschedule so you don’t lose valuable time to no-shows.
By 
upgrading
, you'll be able to set up thoughtful reminders to create meetings that run smoothly, stay on track, and help you reach your goals. It’s a small step with big results.

subject: Join us in Washington DC 🚩
body:
6th annual Dare to Overcome Faith@Work Conference
 
 
Join us in Washington DC
 
6th Annual Fortune 500 Faith@Work ERG Conference
 
Dear Larry Baker, 
Join us in Washington DC for the 6th Annual Fortune 500 Faith@Work ERG conference, May 20-22, 2025 (
register here
). We're thrilled to be back at the Catholic University's Busch School of Business for the 6th year!
We have an exciting and growing list of sponsors including DELL Technologies, Equinix, Merck, American Airlines, Coca-Cola Consolidated, ServiceNow, among others.
In the weeks leading up to the conference, I'll be introducing the exciting elements of the program. This week, meet two of our keynotes!
Super Habits
 
Each year, our most popular keynote has been by the Busch School's Dean Andrew Abela. This year promises to be the best yet, as he unpacks the ancient yet modern secrets to a successful life (and business). 
Everyone registered gets a free copy of his new book, 
Super Habits
: The Universal System for a Successful Life.
Harvard's Arthur C. Brooks says,
 
"A rich blend of social science and ancient wisdom, Andrew Abela's 
Superhabits
 shows how strengthening our virtues leads to well-being. This beautiful book is a must-read for anyone in pursuit of the better life."
 
Brighter Days
 
Get ready for a fun, authentic and inspiring keynote from my friend and colleague, 
Patrick Regan, OBE
.
Patrick's new book, 
Brighter Days
: 12 Steps to Strengthening Your Well-being,
 couldn't be more relevant with all the disruption and divisiveness swirling about. It empowers readers to embrace their struggles while equipping them with the tools needed for a healthier, more fulfilling future. Discover that you are not alone in your journey, and get ready to look forward to brighter days ahead!
Patrick is a sought after mental health provider and founder of three successful NGOs. Boris Johnson gave him the London Peace Award by for his work in the prevention of knife crime and the late Queen Elizabeth II awarded him an OBE for his services to young people. 
 
This 
conference
 is part of our global Dare to Overcome initiative that builds religious freedom for all by expanding the space where people's faiths and beliefs have a place at the table. In a growing number of companies, this is through faith-oriented Employee Resource Groups (ERGs) or chaplaincy programs.
Brian Grim
President, Religious Freedom & Business Foundation
Global Chair, Dare to Overcome 
 
Also, join us in London
 
 
In the News
 
 
The results of a troubling new report about the workplace atmosphere for Jewish people is setting off alarm bells. CBN's Raj Nair is joined by Brian Grim, the President of the Religious Freedom & Business Foundation, to break down the upsetting details.
Radius Research on Employee Resource Groups (ERGs)
 
 
Weekly Feature
 
 
Welcome to this week's edition of Future Trends, the must-read weekly briefing covering the changing face of global politics, economics, development, social and conflict.
Here's what's happening this week: 
► Greenland's opposition in surprise victory
► Syria’s temporary constitution for five-year transition
► US and Israel look to Africa for moving Palestinians from Gaza
► Angola to act as mediator in peace talks between Congo and M23 rebels
► Walmart friction with China after asking suppliers to absorb tariffs
► IMF approves $1.2 billion more for Egypt's economic recovery
► Rwanda cuts ties with Belgium, orders diplomats to leave
► Annual jab for HIV protection passes trial hurdle
► 
More ...
Stay in touch:

subject: Why Racial Inclusion Still Matters
body:
View in browser
 
 
 
READ THE FULL ARTICLE
 
Hi Larry,
Today marks the International Day for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination — a reminder that conversations about race are not only necessary but vital for creating fairer workplaces and communities.
 
Race shapes our environments in both subtle and significant ways, yet many feel uncomfortable addressing it directly. Ignoring these dynamics doesn’t erase them. In fact, when organisations embrace racial inclusion, they see better decision-making, greater innovation, and stronger connections.
 
The question isn’t whether we should talk about race. It’s how we do it in a way that leads to understanding, fairness, and progress.
A racially inclusive, equitable world is a meritocracy.
 
READ THE FULL ARTICLE
 
 
 
Take the next step in embedding inclusion into your workplace.
 
Try our 
Learning Bites
 demo to experience actionable strategies for fostering inclusive behaviours and habits.
Try Demo Now
 
  
Ready to explore the possibilities?
SCHEDULE TIME TO TALK
 
Symmetra Pty Ltd, Quay Quarter Towers, Level 2, 50 Bridge Street, Sydney, NSW 2000 Australia, hello@symmetraglobal.com

body:
Andrea,
 
Go ahead and put me down for all these dates. But mark then as tentative as we go past June. I hope to be working full time somewhere by then.

Aflac has returned with the dates.  Take a look and let me know your interest.  You are contracted for these three sessions, but dates are now as follows:
How Culture Influences Communication 4/23
MBTR (Inclusive Talent Review)  7/17

What a mess.  Here are other dates.  Take a look and let me know if you want me to queue you up to do  I believe that Patricia was to do the one in red.

subject: 1 week to go! Insights from KPMG & Lloyds
body:
Limited spots available - reserve your place today.
 
Neurodiversity at Work: Success Strategies from Leading Brands
 
Live Panel Discussion | March 27, 2025 | 11 AM ET | 3 PM GMT
Register now 
Neurodiversity isn’t just a conversation - it’s a competitive advantage. Yet many organizations still struggle to create environments where neurodivergent employees can truly thrive. 
On March 27, join industry leaders from 
KPMG
, 
Legal & General
, and 
Lloyds 
as they share proven strategies for building more inclusive workplaces that drive innovation, engagement, and business success. 
Why attend
 
Get real-world insights from top brands leading the way in neuroinclusion
 
Learn practical steps to attract, retain, and empower neurodivergent talent 
Understand how neurodiverse teams fuel creativity, problem-solving, and retention
 
This interactive panel discussion is your opportunity to 
ask questions, gain insights, and take away actionable strategies
 
to implement in your own workplace.
Don't miss out 
Meet the experts 
 
Christina Taylor, KPMG 
Inclusion & Equity Manager
 
Christina is a dedicated advocate for inclusion and diversity, particularly for individuals with disabilities, leveraging her professional experience and personal insights to drive positive change. 
 
Mark Lomas, Lloyds 
Head of Culture, Human Resources
 
Mark is a seasoned Diversity & Culture expert with a proven track record in driving impactful change, particularly in the financial services sector. 
 
Jacquline Alcindor, LGIM 
Equity, Inclusion & Diversity Lead
 
With a strong background in banking and an MBA from Westminster University, Jacquline brings strategic thinking and a results-oriented approach to her DEI work. 
Let's build workplaces where every brain can thrive. 
Secure your spot 
Kind regards, 
The Everway team 
formerly Texthelp

subject: Neurodiversity Celebration Week; World Hearing Day; and more!
body:
In this action-packed edition, you'll find:
 
 
Dear colleagues,
In this action-packed edition, you'll find:
1
. Neurodiversity Celebration Week, 
an interview with 
Included 
consultant, Lydia Collins, about her journey as a neurodivergent person.
2. 
World Hearing Day
 was on March 3rd. Learn more about our Director of Operations, Vikki Barron, and her own personal hearing loss journey including the link between hearing loss and long-term brain health.
3. An invitation to our upcoming events: 
 
Breaking Barriers: Beyond the Hashtags, Beyond IWD
Using Data in EDI: Driving Evidence-Based Inclusion Strategies
From Policy to Progress: How EU Directives Can Drive Culture Change 
(Please note new date/time below!)
4. The audio book of our most recent publication ‘
The Key to Inclusion
’ is out now! Rob Adediran shares his key takeaways from the first chapter. There is also a chance of winning a free audio book code!
Click on the links below to dive deeper into each topic.
 
As always, we’re here for any questions or additional information you may need.
 
Warm regards,
Your 
Included
 Team 
  
Neurodiversity Celebration Week
Learn more about 
Included 
consultant Lydia Collins and her journey as a neurodivergent person.
"
I realised I’m just using a different ‘operating system’ to my neurotypical peers. We don’t always think the same way, and that’s great. Knowing this helps me feel more able to be my true self, bringing my unique perspective, experience, and skills to my work.
"
  
Read Now
 
Embracing Hearing Aids: A Game-Changer for Long-Term Health
For World Hearing Day (3rd March), our Director of Operations, Vikki, shared her journey with hearing loss – and why she’s now a proud hearing aid wearer.
"I first noticed my hearing loss in my 30s while working in noisy TV production offices. I’d miss parts of conversations unless I was face-to-face and focused on whomever was speaking. At first, I reluctantly tried hearing aids, but I felt way too young to need them. I convinced myself I could manage without them.
Fast forward a few years, and working remotely at Included allowed me to control my sound environment, making hearing aids feel unnecessary. I thought I had it all figured out...
"
  
Continue reading...
 
Breaking Barriers: Beyond the Hashtags, Beyond IWD
The conversation on equity and inclusion cannot be confined to a single day. As Women’s History Month comes to a close, join us for a powerful and thought-provoking session with keynote speaker 
Dimple Agarwal
, a leader and advocate for equity in the workplace.
In this session, Dimple will bring to life the realities of workplace culture and discrimination, the barriers to real inclusion, and the urgent need for systemic change. Drawing from her extensive experience, both in the corporate world and supporting individuals facing discrimination, she will challenge the myths of corporate progress and provide tangible actions to accelerate action and drive meaningful change. 
  
Sign-up here
 
Using Data in EDI: Driving Evidence-Based Inclusion Strategies
In today’s data-driven world, harnessing the right insights is key to building inclusive workplaces. But how can organisations effectively use data to inform and enhance their EDI strategies?
In this session, discover how to leverage data for meaningful change by:
•    Identifying key metrics that reflect inclusion and equity in your organisation
•    Using data to measure, monitor, and improve EDI initiatives
•    Embedding evidence-based strategies into everyday practices
•    Equipping leaders with insights to drive accountability and inclusive growth
  
Sign-up here
 
Note new time and date: 07 May 2025, 13:00-1400 GMT:
From Policy to Progress: How EU Directives Can Drive Culture Change
With the Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) now in effect and the Gender Representation Directive set to go live next year, companies with an EU presence face an evolving regulatory landscape that extends far beyond pay equity and transparency.
At the same time, organisations in the UK are finalising their gender pay gap submissions, with encouragement to extend to disability and ethnicity pay gap reporting too. Whilst the US may push back on EDI, the rest of the world pushes forward,
Join us for another insightful webinar where, this time, we’ll explore how these EU directives are reshaping workplace expectations and what they mean for your organisation.
  
Sign-up here
 
The Key to Inclusion Audiobook
 
We are delighted to share that our book, 
The Key to Inclusion
, is now available in audio format. This book, written in 2022, is a practical guide to Diversity, Equity and Belonging for You, Your Team and Your Organisation. Recognising the importance of diversity, belonging and equity is not enough and this book has the practical guidance needed to think differently and make true inclusion a reality.
To mark this exciting moment, we are offering you the chance of winning a free audio book code. Please visit the below link for further information. Good Luck!
 
Find out more
 
Find out more about 
Included
’s approach to diversity 
here
 and take a look at our 
Impact Report
. 
Please 
get in touch
 with us anytime to have a conversation about making your organisation more diverse and more inclusive.  We look forward to hearing from you. 
From all of us at 
Included

Included 
email newsletter.

.

subject: 🌍 Bridging the Gap: Strategies for Navigating Hierarchy in Global Teams
body:
Continue reading for navigating hierarchy in global teams. ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Hello Larry!
 
📩
 
Following up on our last email…
We explored how 
power distance
—the level of hierarchy expected in the workplace—can impact team dynamics. When employees hesitate to speak up or leaders unknowingly reinforce hierarchy, inclusion suffers. 
But the good news? 
You can bridge this gap with the right strategies.
 
Here’s how to 
ensure power distance doesn’t hold your team dynamics back.
 
 
🗣️
 
1. Adapt Your Leadership Style
A one-size-fits-all approach won’t work if you’re managing a team with different cultural expectations. In 
high power-distance
 cultures, provide clear structure and guidance while gradually encouraging participation. In 
low power-distance
 cultures, foster open dialogue and collaborative decision-making. 
 
🤝
 
2. Set Clear Expectations Around Participation
Make it known that 
every voice matters.
 Some employees may be used to top-down decision-making, so explicitly state: 
“
Your input is valued, and we encourage different perspectives. As part of our culture, we expect everyone to contribute ideas in meetings.” 
Small shifts in messaging 
signal that participation is not just welcome but expected.
 
 
📊
 
3. Use Different Feedback Channels
For employees hesitant to challenge authority publicly, 
create alternative ways to share feedback 
such as anonymous surveys, private feedback channels, or one-on-one check-ins with leadership. This removes social pressure and 
gives all employees a way to be heard.
 
 
🌟
 
4. Coach Leaders to Be Cultural Translators
Managers play a critical role in bridging power distance. Train them to:
🔹
 Recognize when hierarchy is shaping team dynamics
🔹
 Invite participation in ways that align with cultural norms
🔹
 Create psychologically safe spaces where speaking up isn’t seen as a risk 
 
🚀
 
5. Leverage Mentorship & Sponsorship
Employees from high power-distance cultures may wait for permission to advance. 
Pair them with mentors who encourage self-advocacy and leadership development. 
Sponsorship programs can also help high-potential employees 
gain visibility
 and confidence in contributing. 
 
🎯
 
What’s Next? Let’s Put These Strategies into Action!
Understanding power distance is just the first step—applying it effectively is where the real transformation happens. 
Let’s chat! 
Schedule a complimentary call with me
 to discuss how you can implement these strategies and build a more inclusive, globally aware workplace. 
📅
 
Schedule Your Call Here
 
 
Here’s to creating workplaces where cultural differences matter! 
Bye for now, 
Luiza
___________________________________
 
Luiza Dreasher, Founder and CEO (she/her/hers)
Mastering Cultural Differences 
I work with leaders who want to create a work environment where all employees feel valued and want to stay.
At 
Mastering Cultural Differences LLC,
 we are committed to helping organizations build inclusive, culturally competent workplaces where every individual feels valued and respected. Through highly customized programs, we equip teams with knowledge and skills to help them connect and collaborate more effectively across differences. If you have any questions about this Privacy Policy or need assistance managing your personal information, feel free to contact us at:

luiza@masteringculturaldifferences.com

Continue reading to learn how to protect foreign workers from discrimination and create and inclusive organization. ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌

Dear Larry,
 
❗
 
“I don’t want you in here… Send someone American.”
 
❗
 
Imagine being a skilled, compassionate caregiver—only to be rejected because of your nationality.  
Unfortunately, this happens far too often in healthcare and senior care facilities. 
📢
 In the latest DEI+ Newsletter, 
“
I Want Someone American:” Protecting Foreign Workers from Discrimination
,
 I reveal how bias—whether subtle or explicit—affects workers, damages organizational culture, and violates civil rights. More importantly, I provide actionable strategies to build truly inclusive workplaces where 
every employee feels valued.
 
💡
 And to help you take the next step, I’m also offering 
Bridging Cultures with Care: Fun & Inclusive Activities for Nursing Homes & Assisted Living Facilities
—a resource filled with engaging activities like 
Cultural Bingo, storytelling, and guided conversations 
to foster connection and break down biases. 
 
🔗
 
Read the full article & request your free activities here!
 
📖👇
 
 
 
 Let’s create bias-free work environments 
💪
 
Bye for now!
Luiza

subject: Using fear as FUEL
body:
📅 
Happenings
APRIL FREE WEBINAR
 -
 
Join us for a free open webinar with special guests. 
90 Days In: Reigniting Actionable Allyship in a Defining Moment 
takes place on 
Apr. 23rd at 1pm ET.
 Join Julie Kratz, Dr. Akilah Cadet, and Karen Catlin for a conversation tackling tough but necessary conversations on allyship, action, and accountability. Learn how to move beyond performative gestures, re-engage meaningfully, and navigate discomfort in today’s political and social climate. Whether you’re setting boundaries, or taking your activism further, this session is for you. 
Register for free here
.
​
INTERNATIONAL ALLYSHIP DAY
 - Join us in NYC or virtually on August 8th for our 
2nd annual International Allyship Day event
, hosted by our partner AllianceBernstein. This year’s focus is on equipping inclusion and ERG leaders with actionable strategies to strengthen or launch allyship programs within their organizations. Participants will gain essential skills for effective allyship, pushback-proof strategies, and insights into the strategic business impact of allyship. They’ll also have the chance to connect with senior leaders in the inclusion space. We're consistently adding exciting new speakers and organizations like Coqual and Dr. Sandra Upton - 
will your organization be there?
 
Register individually or as a team here
.
​
 
​
📝 Using fear as FUEL
In a perpetually chaotic world, finding meaning can be a powerful antidote.
Last week, I wrote about my experiences at the National Afterschool Association conference with apathy towards diversity, equity and inclusion work. The work week proved to be more interesting on Thursday. A surprise illness in our team's family led to me leading an impromptu 4:00 a.m. session on state of women in the workplace for our international colleagues followed by another presentation for US based employees, with an afternoon video shoot for our new speaking reel. 
By Friday, I was fried, and I had set a goal to finish the last chapter of the new book I am writing about people with power and how they can be better allies. Maybe you can relate if you've had a grueling week, it feels like you're getting punked!
However, I didn't realize there was more in store for us. My daughter has been wrestling with what we thought to be food allergies and stomach pains the last 2 months. It became quite clear that something was seriously wrong so we rushed her to the ER on Friday all to discover that she had a significant health issue that required emergency surgery. Thankfully we live very close to a fantastic children's hospital and she was able to even come home Saturday and go to school this week. 
I'm not sharing this for pity or even commiseration, but if you've had a rough week like this, it's a great reminder of what's important in life. Whether it's the news headlines, or work that you're passionate about feels like it's going away, or your own personal or professional struggles, hope remains. 
I'm practicing a new mantra about 
turning my fear into fuel
.
 It's not easy. There will be more weeks like last week. However, I'm super thankful my team gets to do work with purpose and my family is safe and healthy. That's what really matters. 
Thanks allies,
Julie
​
💬 
Allyship Conversation Starters & Resources
The 
tech industry can’t afford to ignore diversity
​
​
 
​
Survey: 
Nearly one-third of employees have felt excluded or marginalized at work in the last five years
​
​
 
Care about inclusion for the little ones in your life? Check out the programs and resources from 
LITTLE ALLIES
, a nonprofit working to facilitate inclusive experiences for all children to feel seen, heard, and belong.
​
Next Pivot Point
 
works to promote allyship and inclusion across all dimensions of diversity in the workplace to make sure everyone feels seen, heard, and belonging at work.
​
Next Pivot Point
​

subject: A new fear index
body:
Plus: knowing when to step down. 
March 19, 2025  ·  
View in browser
 
The Insightful Leader
BY 
KELLOGG INSIGHT
Leadership advice from the Kellogg School of Management at Northwestern University
Good morning, 
When it comes to the stock market, many of us adhere to the mantra “set it and forget it.” We prefer a simple and easy approach to investing so that we can focus our attention on our careers and family.
But the market’s recent volatility has made it hard to ignore. This may be especially true for leaders who like to keep their finger on the pulse of their industry, with the well-being of their colleagues and company in mind.
This week, we’ll take a look at two new indices built by Kellogg’s 
Viktor Todorov
 and 
Torben Andersen
 to help people better understand stock market volatility.
Plus, Kellogg’s 
Dean Karlan
 discusses his decision to resign as chief economist of the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID).
A new fear index
Since 1993, the Cboe Volatility Index (VIX) has offered investors a real-time measure of stock market volatility: namely, how much the market expects prices on the S&P 500 to change over the next 30 days. For this reason, the VIX is also commonly called the “fear index.”
“When things really go bad, people start mentioning, ‘Oh, the VIX is at a very, very high level,’” says Kellogg’s Viktor Todorov.
But despite VIX’s popularity, Todorov and Andersen believe it is hardly the pure measure of volatility or fear that many investors believe. Specifically, they argue that VIX combines into a single measure both investors’ expectations about the S&P 500’s day-to-day volatility and their fears of a rare but catastrophic (or “tail”) event that tanks equity prices.
To address these shortcomings, the economists have built two new indices, listed on Cboe alongside VIX, that separately capture these two aspects: the Cboe S&P 500 Spot Volatility Index (SPOTVOL), which focuses on immediate market fluctuations, and the Cboe S&P 500 Left Tail Volatility Index (LTV), which tracks concern over extreme tail events.
Read more about the indices in 
Kellogg Insight
.
 
Stepping down
When Dean Karlan received the call to take up the mantle of USAID chief economist in 2022, he was both intimidated and thrilled.
USAID—which at the time managed the world’s largest bilateral aid portfolio—had recognized Karlan’s research in poverty reduction and invited him to lead the agency’s efforts to make its work more cost-effective. “That was an ask that was daunting and exciting and why I got into this work in the first place,” he says in a 
recent podcast
.
Karlan set out to identify approaches in the agency that weren’t working so well and to further improve those that were.
“We did this work by looking at how decisions were made,” he says, “looking at what was being funded, looking at what the evidence said about the impact of those things, and seeing what the evidence says about alternatives that might be better.”
So when the presidential administration announced at the end of January its decision to eliminate the vast majority of USAID’s foreign aid contracts, Karlan pushed for an examination of the evidence that went into the decision-making process. That, he believes, was his responsibility in his leadership position. But his appeals were disregarded.
“All patterns indicated that there was nothing resembling evidence of impact that was being used to guide what they were doing, and they were not open to input along those lines,” Karlan says. “It was clear that there was no role for what I was trying to do.”
Though he could have held onto his title (his position was not one of the roughly 2,000 flagged for dismissal), Karlan chose to step down instead. He recognized that his role as a leader at the agency was no longer serving its intended purpose.
Hear more from Karlan on 
WBEZ’s Reset
 podcast.
“The answer lies not in resisting automation but in designing AI systems that augment human capability rather than replace it.”
— 
Mohanbir Sawhney
, in 
Business Today
, on how AI is becoming the next great frontier for countries like India.
See you next week,
Abraham Kim, senior research editor
Kellogg Insight
Follow us on 
LinkedIn
.
And listen to our 
podcasts
.
Kellogg School of Management
 | 
2211 Campus Drive
, 
Evanston, IL 60208

 March 18, 2025
DEI has become undoubtedly one of the most polarized topics in today's workplace. While some attribute the backlash to misinformation, what if the real issue is how we—DEI advocates—have framed and communicated these concepts? Our team has recently written about this challenge, not to assign blame but to foster understanding. How did we get here, and how can we do better? Whether you champion DEI initiatives or have doubts, we invite you to read, listen, and share your perspective.
 
 
– Team Aleria
DEI Backlash: 
Pros
 and 
Cons
Stories focused on the anti-DEI backlash, and efforts to put a stop to the nonsense!
 
Quantifying DEI
Exploring the tangible aspects of DEI and current efforts to quantify it
 
DEI Resources
Useful tools and information to support your DEI efforts
 
The Complexity of DEI
Unintended consequences and ripple effects of DEI
 
Golden Nuggets,
 Silver Linings
Unexpected bits of good news... when we can find them.
Congratulations to Louis Chesney, whose consulting work on the film 
Magnetospher
 has contributed to its selection as one of fourteen feature films to be screened at the 
ReelAbilities Film Festival New York
—the world's largest festival dedicated to showcasing films that celebrate the stories and talents of people with disabilities.
We're also pleased to see 
female influencers bridging the gap 
between traditional media in a male-dominated sport and a growing online fan base of women. And, of course, kudos to the 
nine companies leading the way
 with policies that break down barriers to workforce participation—and are seeing the results!
 
 
Aleria Happenings
The latest from the Aleria Team

🎙️

: 
“Measuring Inclusion: Higher profits and happier people, without guesswork or backlash”
🎙️

:

The Real Business Case for Inclusion: Measuring What Matters"
🎙️
The Future Talent Council interview
:

 — a written version of the interview is 
also available, download it 
here
.
 
Embrace a new approach to DEI! Find out how focusing on inclusion leads to greater, sustainable diversity while driving superior performance for 
any
 organization, creating alignment instead of backlash. 
Visit our website
 for additional information, 
send us an email
 to learn more, or use the button below to schedule a call with Aleria's Founder and Chief Scientist, Paolo Gaudiano, who can provide more details and answer any questions about how measuring inclusion can give your organization a competitive advantage.
Book a call with Paolo

The presentation includes case studies and resources that you can use in your own organization.

subject: Smart Strategies for Gen AI in Law Firms (Wise Decision Maker Guide 147)
body:
Wise Decision Maker Guide 
 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
Greetings Larry,
Generative AI offers law firms opportunities to improve efficiency and client service, but ethical risks must be carefully managed. For example, several recent cases resulted in fines for lawyers who provided fictitious citations that were obtained through Gen AI. In response, the American Bar Association issued Formal Opinion 512, reinforcing that ethical obligations under the ABA Model Rules of Professional Conduct remain critical when using Gen AI. Lawyers must ensure accuracy, safeguard client confidentiality, communicate AI use transparently, and uphold reasonable billing practices. 
Law firms that want to take advantage of AI’s potential must prioritize training, clear policies, and human verification.
To learn more, check out this
 
blog
.
Read Blog
 
Prefer video to text? See this 
video
 based on the blog:
If you prefer audio, listen to this 
podcast
 based on the blog:
Make Your Voice Heard
Vote in this 
LinkedIn poll
 to contribute to the conversation. I will use the responses to inform my articles in 
Harvard Business Review
, 
Fortune
, and 
Entrepreneur
.
Your Testimonials
You and others who gain value from Disaster Avoidance Experts 
services
 and thought leadership occasionally share testimonials about your experience, such as the one below. You can read more testimonials 
here
.
“I wanted to thank you for speaking recently at our Spring 2024 National Legal Malpractice Conference. We really enjoyed having you and hearing you discuss proximity bias. It was really a worthwhile event and conversation for our panel who really didn't know a great deal about it or a lot of the implications related to it. We 
really appreciated all the energy and obvious underlying knowledge that you have related to the topic.
 All of our panelists really enjoyed hearing from you, our guests enjoyed hearing from you, and we look forward to working with you again.”
‌
Jay Reyes
, 
Chief Counsel at the American Bar Association
Schedule a Free Consultation
 
What's Up With Me
My wife and business partner, Agnes Vishnevkin, and Iwere making our plans to travel from our hometown of Columbus, Ohio, to visit my parents for my mom’s 75th birthday in New York City. At the same time, she’s been struggling with a period of back pain for the past two months. Her condition fluctuated, but it was worse again in the days leading up to the trip, so I suggested she should skip the trip. She was quite reluctant to do so, because she was concerned that my mother would be upset. I was surprised how hard it was to convince her to agree to stay home.
This is the kind of situation where she and I differ: I tend to think people will understand and forgive, while she is more worried about others’ judgments. Maybe sometimes I underestimate how judgmental people might be, but in this case I think I was right. Sometimes, we need to reduce our concerns about other people’s opinions and focus on our own self-care. Now, that doesn’t mean being a jerk, there has to be a balance, but in this case the balance to me was clearly toward self-care. 
What do you think should be the balance between self-care and consideration of other people’s feelings?
 
Would love to get your feedback on what you found most useful about this edition of the “Wise Decision Maker Guide” - simply reply to this email.
Decisively Yours,
Dr. Gleb
Dr. Gleb Tsipursky
CEO of Disaster Avoidance Experts

Dear Larry,
 
Are you a practitioner searching for the latest updates on pay equality given changing federal mandates?  You won’t want to miss Trusaic’s upcoming webinar, 
Think Pay Equality is Going Away? Think Again—Here’s What’s Next
, featuring our legal experts, Maxfield Marquardt, Nasar Khan, and former OFCCP Director, Craig Leen.
 
They will share regulatory updates and insights on how the definition of pay equality is changing at the federal level and how that applies to your organization.
 
Other takeaways include:
Why state pay equality laws, transparency mandates, and pay data reporting remain in full force despite federal changes.
How pay equality audits serve as a key safeguard against pay discrimination and legal risk.
The growing risk of pay related litigation, including “reverse discrimination” lawsuits, and how organizations can mitigate exposure.
How Trusaic’s PayParity® software supports a compliant, risk-proof approach to pay equality strategy.
Register Today!
 
 
Trusaic, 520 S Grand Ave, Suite 200, Los Angeles, CA 90071, United States, 213-382-1115

subject: removing DEI means removing mention of specific identities
body:
To the current admin, ‘removing DEI’ seems to mean removing any mention of identities. In other words, complete minimization and an ‘we’re all human beings’ approach. Another example here, where the Defense Dept has removed webpages and language that specifically call out Native American and women’s contributions.
 
 
Amid ‘DEI’ purge, Pentagon removes webpage on Iwo Jima flag-raiser.
 
Pages celebrating Navajo code talkers and other minority service members were also erased.

subject: 📢 Are Hidden Hierarchies Holding Your Inclusion Efforts Back?
body:
Continue reading for...... ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Hello Larry!
 
🛑
 
Picture this:
You’ve launched a new initiative, encouraging employees to share their ideas and concerns. Your goal? An inclusive workplace where everyone feels heard. 
Yet, in some global teams, silence fills the room. Junior employees hesitate to speak in meetings. Some leaders make decisions with little input from their teams. And despite your efforts, true inclusivity feels out of reach. 
 
🤔
 
The Experience:
Imagine a new hire from a hierarchical culture—where questioning leadership is seen as disrespectful. When asked for feedback, they stay quiet, unsure if speaking up is truly welcome. Meanwhile, their manager—accustomed to top-down leadership—assumes silence means agreement. 
The result? 
Missed perspectives, disengaged employees, and stalled progress on your goals.
 
 
⚠️
 
The Problem:
Global teams bring diverse perspectives, but power distance—the level of hierarchy people expect in the workplace—shapes how employees engage. In 
high power-distance cultures
, hierarchy is respected, and decisions flow from the top. In 
low power-distance cultures
, employees expect open dialogue and shared decision-making. 
When these cultural expectations clash:
❌
 Employees from hierarchical cultures hesitate to challenge authority.
❌
 Leaders from egalitarian cultures struggle to engage hierarchical teams.
❌
 Critical workplace discussions remain one-sided, limiting real change. 
 
💡
 
The Future You’re Waiting For:
Now, imagine an organization where:
✅
 Every employee—regardless of background—feels empowered to contribute.
✅
 Leaders recognize and adapt to different cultural expectations.
✅
 Inclusion initiatives succeed because engagement isn’t dictated by hierarchy. 
 
🎤
 
What’s Next?
In my next email, I’ll share 
specific strategies
 to navigate power distance effectively—so you can foster a truly inclusive workplace without cultural misalignment holding you back. Stay tuned! 
 
Bye for now, 
Luiza
___________________________________
 
Luiza Dreasher, Founder and CEO (she/her/hers)
Mastering Cultural Differences 
I work with leaders who want to create a work environment where all employees feel valued and want to stay.
At 
Mastering Cultural Differences LLC,
 we are committed to helping organizations build inclusive, culturally competent workplaces where every individual feels valued and respected. Through highly customized programs, we equip teams with knowledge and skills to help them connect and collaborate more effectively across differences. If you have any questions about this Privacy Policy or need assistance managing your personal information, feel free to contact us at: 
www.masteringculturaldifferences.com

luiza@masteringculturaldifferences.com

subject: Re: GroupM further delays
body:
OK. Well, I hope they are still going to reschedule soon!!
Sent via the Samsung Galaxy S22+ 5G, an AT&T 5G smartphone
Get 
Outlook for Android
From:
 Rebecca Parrilla <r.parrilla@lcwmail.com>
Sent:
 Monday, March 17, 2025 1:24:33 PM
To:
 Larry Baker <l.baker@lcwmail.com>
Cc:
 Chuck Adams <c.adams@lcwmail.com>; Juri Mansour <j.mansour@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 GroupM further delays
 
 
Hi Larry, happy St. Patrick’s Day!
We had a meeting with GroupM this morning and they are once again pushing back their 2025 launch due to internal legal/comms reviews plus now they are modifying their registration process and want a chance to test that out too. It seems like they won’t be starting until late April earliest, though we don’t have an exact date yet because there are several unknowns right now (still on Mondays and Fridays). Juri and I are following up on a couple of requests and are moving as quickly as we can so that delays cannot be attributed to us. I’m sorry about this back-and-forth, I understand how it could be affecting your planning. Sadly, we’re doing all we possibly can to get this started and yet here we are. 
 
RP 
 
Rebecca M. Parrilla

I am contacting you today because I see that your organization is qualified for a business account with Amazon; our buying solution that grows with your business.
There are zero fees to setup the account, and there is no minimum spending amount needed to maintain the account. These are some of the benefits of shopping on Amazon Business for your organization:
 
Business Savings:

Cash flow optimization:
 Manage your cash flow more efficiently with our buy now – pay later payment options.
Free Amazon Business Prime:

subject: 5 Things: Chicagoland's Weekly Business Update
body:
Delivered by Southwest Airlines 
 
Click 
here
 
to view this email in your browser.
 
 
 
 
 
Weekly Business Update 
March 17, 2025
Delivered by
 
MEMBER NEWS
Register Today for J.P. Morgan Corporate Challenge Chicago! 
PRESENTED BY
 JPMORGANCHASE 
 
An iconic event since 1982, the J.P. Morgan Corporate Challenge Chicago returns Thursday, May 8, at 6:50 p.m. at Grant Park. The 3.5-mile run/walk is phenomenally popular with the business community, both for the healthy competition and post-race party. Spots are available for all businesses in Chicagoland, with a minimum team size of four and no maximum. Registration for both Team Captains and Participants closes on Thursday, April 10 at 8:00 p.m. 
REGISTER NOW
 
MEMBER NEWS
Learn About Business & Tech Apprenticeships on National Apprenticeship Day 
PRESENTED BY CITY COLLEGES OF CHICAGO
 
Join City Colleges of Chicago and the Chicago Apprentice Network on National Apprenticeship Day, April 30, 2025, for a Business & Tech Apprenticeship Summit. This unique event will highlight the companies of all sizes that work with City Colleges on customized apprenticeship programs in the business and technology industries. It's the perfect opportunity to get your questions answered and network with others who have hired City Colleges apprentices as a successful talent strategy. 
REGISTER NOW
 
UPCOMING EVENT
Make Your Next Professional Connection at Nisos Prime on March 19 
PRESENTED BY THE CHICAGOLAND CHAMBER OF COMMERCE
 
Attend the Chicagoland Chamber of Commerce’s Business After Business networking event hosted by Nisos Prime on March 19. Attendees will have the opportunity to network with local professionals within a distinctive warm and welcoming hospitality, set against a stunningly designed backdrop. Register now before it's too late! Business After Business, the Chamber’s monthly networking happy hours, ensure you make the connections you need — and want — to grow your business.
REGISTER NOW
 
MEMBER NEWS
Attend the Spring Citywide Career Fair
PRESENTED BY THE CHICAGO TRANSIT AUTHORITY
 
Join the Chicago Transit Authority for the Spring Citywide Career Fair on Wednesday, April 23, 2025, at Olive-Harvey College. From 10:00 AM to 2:00 PM, meet with top employers, explore career opportunities across industries, and take the next step toward your professional goals. Pre-registration is strongly recommended to streamline your experience, but walk-ins are welcome. Don’t miss this chance to connect with hiring professionals and discover new opportunities!
REGISTER NOW
 
CHAMBER NEWS
The Chicagoland Chamber of Commerce Will Never Sell Your Data 
PRESENTED BY THE CHICAGOLAND CHAMBER OF COMMERCE
 
As a reminder, the Chicagoland Chamber of Commerce values your privacy and will never sell your contact information. Recently, phishing attempts have targeted our members with fraudulent offers to sell member information. Please know that we do not share your personal data with third parties outside of necessary operations. To stay informed on how we protect your data, we encourage you to review our full Privacy Statement on our website. If you have any questions or concerns, feel free to reach out to us directly. Thank you for your vigilance in helping us maintain a secure community. 
LEARN MORE
 
Want to showcase your company news, information, products, or services?
 
Chamber members are able to take advantage of a myriad of benefits to help your business grow, including inclusion in this email newsletter. With a broad distribution, you can gain access to a new audience that you may not otherwise be able to reach.
REVIEW BENEFITS
 
 
FOLLOW THE CHAMBER
 
 
 
 
 
WWW.CHICAGOLANDCHAMBER.ORG
The Chicagoland Chamber of Commerce
The Wrigley Building | 410 N Michigan Ave | Suite 900
Chicago, IL 60611

 at any time.

Privacy Policy

subject: GroupM further delays
body:
Hi Larry, happy St. Patrick’s Day!
We had a meeting with GroupM this morning and they are once again pushing back their 2025 launch due to internal legal/comms reviews plus now they are modifying their registration process and want a chance to test that out too. It seems like they won’t be starting until late April earliest, though we don’t have an exact date yet because there are several unknowns right now (still on Mondays and Fridays). Juri and I are following up on a couple of requests and are moving as quickly as we can so that delays cannot be attributed to us. I’m sorry about this back-and-forth, I understand how it could be affecting your planning. Sadly, we’re doing all we possibly can to get this started and yet here we are. 
 
RP 
 
Rebecca M. Parrilla
 
(MBA, Latina, LGBTQ, Mom)
(she/her) 
Why pronouns matter
Head of Client Solutions
We help develop the mindsets and systems needed to foster resilient, diverse, and equitable teams that will be successful in a cross-cultural world.
Website
 
|
 
Facebook
 
|
 
LinkedIn
 
I live and work in Chapel Hill, NC – on the traditional homelands of the Occaneechi, Shakori, Eno, and Sissipahaw peoples.
