subject: Take Action: Register Before April 1 for the Lowest Rate for the Summit
body:
Your chance to learn from 50+ expert speakers at the 2025 Justice for All Summit: The Power of Inclusion
 
Diversity, equity, and inclusion is being targeted — how will you respond?
 
As efforts to roll back diversity, equity, and inclusion intensify, now is the time to reclaim the power of inclusion. At the 
2025 Justice for All Summit: The Power of Inclusion
, we’re bringing together thought leaders in the fields of diversity, equity, inclusion, accessibility, and justice to explore bold solutions that drive real impact.
 
With 
6 powerful keynotes, 60+ sessions, and 50+ expert speakers
, this is your chance to gain the insights and strategies needed to champion inclusion in your organization and beyond.
 
If you’re planning to attend, 
act now because rates increase April 1!
 
Register now at the lowest rate for yourself or your team (group discounts available!) and invest in a more inclusive future.
Register for the 2025 Justice for All Summit
 
 
What to Expect:
50+ dynamic speakers
 and 
6 keynote sessions
 featuring leading experts and changemakers
Engaging sessions on 
Inclusive Leadership
, 
Psychological Safety
, 
Neurodiversity
, 
Allyship
, 
Tech and AI
, 
Burnout
, and much more
Networking opportunities
 to connect with like-minded professionals
Performing artists
 and wellness corners to rejuvenate your spirit
This summit is your chance to deepen your knowledge, build actionable strategies, and leave with tools to create meaningful, lasting change in your organization.
Register for the 2025 Justice for All Summit
 
 
The 2024 Racial Justice at Work Summit: Justice for All won the Gold Stevie® Award for Event of the Year!
More than 1,500 entries from organizations and individuals in 36 nations and territories were submitted this year for consideration in more than 100 categories. We are proud to be recognized and can't wait to continue the momentum April 21-24, 2025.
 
We need to stand united in our support of diversity, equity, and inclusion — and each other. The transformation starts here with your commitment and support.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
The Winters Group, 8116 South Tryon Street, Ste. B3-260, Charlotte, North Carolina 28273, United States

subject: March 2025 4-Up Friday
body:
March 2025 4-Up Friday
 
View this email in your browser
 
 
As we step into March, we turn our focus to the 
powerful connection between coaching and mentoring
. We will explore how coaching principles can enhance mentoring relationships, foster deeper learning, self-awareness, and growth for both mentors and mentees.
We’re excited to welcome 
Professor David Clutterbuck
 to our 
Thought Leader Conversation
 on 
March 26th
 to discuss
 the role coaching plays in a mentoring relationship
. He is a global authority and pioneer in coaching and mentoring, David and Lisa will discuss how integrating coaching techniques can elevate mentoring conversations, creating more impactful and dynamic relationships. Tune in for insights that will transform the way you approach mentoring!
Mentor On!
The 
Center for Mentoring Excellence Team
 
FOUR UP FRIDAY
 
We love this quote; it captures the complementary nature of both roles - coaching as a guiding force and mentoring as a journey of self-discovery.
 
"A coach tells you what you need to know, a mentor helps you discover what you need to learn."
 - Unknown
 
Join us for our upcoming 
Thought Leader Conversations
! 
Our 
March
 Thought Leader Conversation features 
Professor David Clutterbuck
, a global authority and pioneer in 
coaching and mentoring
. As co-founder of the European Mentoring & Coaching Council and author of over 80 books, David will share how coaching principles can elevate mentoring relationships and drive impactful results.
In 
April
, 
Javier Peña
, musician, keynote speaker, and founder of 
Leading in Tune™
, will explore the power of 
harmony in mentoring
, drawing from his experience using music to foster leadership and teamwork.
In 
June
, 
Jason VanDevere
, entrepreneur, speaker, and founder of 
Goal Crazy Ltd
., will discuss 
goal setting in mentoring
, sharing insights from his best-selling Goal Crazy Planner and his expertise in helping individuals turn ambitious dreams into reality.
 
We are celebrating 
five years
 of 
Bridging Differences for Better Mentoring
! This book has helped countless mentors and mentees foster inclusivity and create meaningful connections. Share your mentoring stories with us using 
#BridgingDifferences
 and 
stay tuned for more anniversary celebrations over the next few weeks!
 
Here are 2 books recommended by our March Thought Leader, Professor David Clutterbuck.  David suggests 
Coaching the Team at Work
 (2nd edition)—a groundbreaking book that applies a complex, adaptive systems approach to team coaching.
He also recommends 
Everyone Needs a Mentor
, the first book to define developmental mentoring and inspire mentoring programs beyond North America. These insightful reads offer invaluable perspectives for anyone looking to deepen their understanding of mentoring and coaching!
Copyright © 2025 Center for Mentoring Excellence, All rights reserved.
You are receiving this email because you opted in via our website.
Our mailing address is:
Center for Mentoring Excellence
3040 78th Ave SE Unit 1173
Mercer Island
, 
WA
 
98040-3694
Add us to your address book
Want to change how you receive these emails?
You can 
update your preferences
 or 
unsubscribe from this list
.

subject: Keynote Ben Cohen Knows Inclusion is the Cherry on Top of a Successful Business
body:
Learn How Inclusion is the Cherry on Top of a Successful Business with Ben Cohen at the Power of Inclusion Summit!
 
 
Learn How Inclusion is the Cherry on Top of a Successful Business with Ben Cohen!
 
 
Grab a pint of Chunky Monkey or Cherry Garcia and settle in for an intimate conversation with Ben & Jerry’s co-founder, Ben Cohen, as he talks leadership, inclusion, social responsibility, and what it takes for a company to live its values out loud and be wildly successful.
 
We are excited to have Ben as one of our Keynote Speakers at the 
2025 Justice for All Summit: The Power of Inclusion.
Reserve Your Seat at the Summit
 
More about Ben:
Ben Cohen and his long-time friend and business partner Jerry Greenfield are the men behind one of the most talked-about—and least conventional— success stories in American business.
 
Co- founder of Ben & Jerry’s Homemade, Inc., Ben helped to build a storefront venture into a $300 million publicly held ice cream empire by making social responsibility and creative management strengths instead of weaknesses. Despite Ben’s efforts to keep the company independent, it was sold to Unilever in 2000.  Ben and Jerry’s worldwide sales are now $1.2 Billion. 
 
His book Values- Driven Business: How to Change the World, Make Money, and Have Fun provides a road map for starting a successful business that is environmentally and socially conscious. Using real-life examples, the books shows how “triple bottom line” practices - profits, people, and planet—have helped businesses thrive.
 
Ben and his co-author, Mal Warwick, also address the varied roles of customers, employees, the community, the environment, shareholders, and owners.
Register Now
 
More about The 2025 Justice for All Summit: The Power of Inclusion
 
What is the Justice for All Summit?
The third annual Justice for All Summit, being held April 21-24, 2025, is the premier virtual conference to connect, get inspired, and learn innovative strategies for cultural transformation through diversity, equity, inclusion, and justice practices.
Who attends?
This restorative space brings together between 500 - 750 HR practitioners, executives, team leaders, learning and development staff, corporate trainers, organizational development professionals, and diversity practitioners in community for learning, networking, and personal/professional development.
 
Who is The Winters Group?
Proudly Black women-owned and -led, The Winters Group has helped organizations strategically increase their capacity to be more culturally competent, create sustainable equitable policies, and foster inclusive workplaces since 1984.
Reserve Your Seat
 
 
 
 
 
The Winters Group, 8116 South Tryon Street, Ste. B3-260, Charlotte, North Carolina 28273, United States

subject: In Case You Missed It #56: The rise in remote work and its impact on productivity and more
body:
ICYMI 
 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
Greetings Larry,
To help you filter the signal from the noise, I curated the most valuable articles I came across recently in case you missed them.
“
The rise in remote work since the pandemic and its impact on productivity
” (BLS.gov)
Summary
The COVID-19 pandemic sparked a dramatic increase in remote work, with many industries adopting work-from-home arrangements. By 2021, remote work participation had surged, especially in professional, scientific, and technical services, as well as information and finance industries. The rise in remote work contributed positively to Total Factor Productivity (TFP) growth across 61 private-sector industries, particularly through reduced nonlabor costs, such as office space expenses.
From 2019 to 2022, the increase in remote work was linked to a 1.1 percentage-point rise in industry-level productivity, with companies benefiting from lower turnover and operational efficiencies. However, productivity gains were not passed to employees through higher compensation. Instead, workers reaped indirect benefits, such as reduced commuting time and expenses. Despite these advantages, industries varied in their ability to balance output and labor input. For most high-productivity sectors, output growth outpaced labor input increases, indicating efficient use of remote work.
Dr. Gleb’s Take
This study confirms that remote work isn’t just a convenience—it’s a powerful driver of productivity and cost-efficiency. Businesses that adapt to remote or hybrid models are gaining a competitive edge, leveraging reduced office space and operational costs while enhancing employee retention.
However, the failure to share these productivity gains with employees reflects shortsighted leadership. Workers saved time and money on commuting, but organizations missed an opportunity to strengthen loyalty by sharing financial benefits to support workers being more productive and comfortable in their home offices. I always advise my clients to invest into employee home offices, such as good tech, ergonomic furniture, and fast internet, which is a win-win for employees and companies alike. 
The data is clear: remote work is not a temporary pandemic solution but a sustainable model for the future of work. Leaders who embrace and optimize this shift will outperform competitors who cling to outdated, office-centric paradigms.
“
Baby boomers say they don’t need to retire now that they can work from home—and they’ve got side hustles on top of their 9-to-5’s
” (Fortune)
Summary
Remote and hybrid work have reshaped retirement plans for baby boomers, allowing them to extend their careers while enjoying better work-life balance. A survey by Smart Energy GB found that nearly 70% of those over 60 are working in hybrid roles, while others work remotely full-time. Without the stress of commuting, many baby boomers are energized to take on side hustles, with tutoring being the most popular choice.
The flexibility of remote work has enabled 25% of surveyed boomers to explore new hobbies they had planned for retirement, such as gardening, yoga, and walking. This dual approach to career and leisure has left 66% feeling less stressed, 94% reporting a renewed zest for life, and 90% expressing satisfaction with their careers.
Globally, the trend of “unretiring” is growing. In the U.K., 14% of baby boomers and late Gen Xers have returned to work, with an additional 4% considering it. In the U.S., the share of workers aged 65 and older has nearly doubled since the 1980s, with 20% of that age group now employed. Many older workers cite financial concerns as a key reason for staying in or returning to the workforce.
Dr. Gleb’s Take
This is a striking testament to the transformative power of remote work. Baby boomers have cracked the code to achieving both financial security and personal fulfillment in their later years. By eliminating the daily grind of commuting, remote work has given them the flexibility to maintain their income while pursuing hobbies and even side gigs.
Employers should take note: offering hybrid or fully remote roles is not just a perk—it’s a retention strategy for experienced, highly skilled workers. Boomers bring decades of expertise, and their willingness to stay in the workforce longer is a massive asset to businesses willing to adapt to their needs.
The "unretiring" trend also highlights a cultural shift. Work is no longer seen as a binary choice between career and retirement. Instead, flexible models enable older workers to blend income, passion projects, and personal growth. Companies that fail to embrace this model risk losing out on a wealth of institutional knowledge and leadership from seasoned a multigenerational workforce. 
"
Matt Yglesias Considered As The Nietzschean Superman
" (Astral Codex Ten)
Summary
This piece explores Nietzsche's concepts of "master morality" and "slave morality," contrasting their historical roots and societal impacts. Master morality celebrates strength, achievement, and individual excellence, while slave morality emphasizes humility, equality, and harm reduction. The article critiques both frameworks, noting that slave morality often manifests as an obsession with diminishing oneself or others to avoid judgment, while master morality can devolve into arrogance and disregard for communal well-being.
Through diverse examples—from Puritans and Soviet propaganda to Ayn Rand and modern liberalism—the essay navigates attempts to reconcile these moralities. Figures like Ayn Rand and Richard Hanania represent different approaches to integrating Nietzschean ideas into modern frameworks. The author concludes by endorsing a "spiral of values," where altruism and ambition coexist in a dynamic balance to glorify civilization and improve human happiness.
Dr. Gleb’s Take
This essay is a masterful exploration of moral frameworks, and gets at a key point: the dichotomy of master and slave morality is too simplistic for the complexity of modern life. Both approaches contain dangerous extremes—unchecked master morality fosters exploitation and harm, while uncritical slave morality stifles innovation and achievement.
The path forward isn’t in choosing one over the other or crafting tenuous compromises like “liberal democracy.” It’s in embracing 
adaptive morality
: a system where individuals and societies balance personal excellence with collective good. This means rewarding ambition when it uplifts others and challenging humility when it becomes performative or self-defeating.
Nietzsche’s Superman isn’t a literal figure—it’s a call to evolve past outdated binaries. We need a vision that values strength as a tool for service and humility as a path to growth. That’s how you build a world where ambition thrives without crushing the vulnerable.
What did you think of my take on these articles? Look forward to hearing from you, simply reply to this email with your thoughts.
Decisively yours,
Dr. Gleb
Dr. Gleb Tsipursky
CEO of Disaster Avoidance Experts
Let's Connect!
Disaster Avoidance Experts is a social enterprise dedicated to promoting science-based truth-seeking and wise decision-making. All profits are donated to 
Intentional Insights
, an educational 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization, and its 
Pro-Truth Pledge
 project.

Join us for a webinar where we’ll  unpack pay equity and pay gap reporting.
 
 
Dear Larry,
 
Want to improve your pay reporting processes and promote pay equity at your organization? If so, register for Trusaic’s WorldatWork webinar 
at 
9 a.m. PT, March 19,
 where experts from Trusaic, Aon, and Workday, will share their knowledge on pay equity and pay gap reporting.
 
By the end of this webinar, participants will have a clear understanding of:
The key differences between compensation data and payroll data.
Why payroll data should never be used for remediating pay inequities.
How to proactively address pay inequities through compensation data analysis before submitting pay gap reports.
The role of contextual narratives in minimizing risk and providing clarity to employees, regulators, and the public.
Actionable insights to improve pay reporting processes and promote pay equity.
Register today!
Register Now
 
 
Trusaic, 520 S Grand Ave, Suite 200, Los Angeles, CA 90071, United States, 213-382-1115

subject: 🔓 Unlocking Leadership Potential: Breaking the “Positive” Stereotype Barrier
body:
Continue reading to learn more about the impact of stereotypes in the workplace. ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Hello Larry!
 
👋
 
Remember Mei from my last email?
 The high-performing employee whose career stalled because she was seen as a great worker—but not a leader? 
She’s not alone.  
When positive stereotypes limit career growth, organizations lose out on diverse leadership, innovation, and employee engagement.
 
But here’s the good news: 
You have the power to change this.
  
Here are 
five actionable strategies
 to dismantle the hidden barriers of “positive” stereotypes in your workplace:
 
1️⃣ 
Redefine Leadership Beyond the Traditional Mold
Too often, leadership is defined by outdated, Western-centric traits—assertiveness, outspokenness, and charisma. 
Expand your definition
 to value diverse leadership styles like collaboration, cultural intelligence, and thoughtful decision-making.  
Ask yourself:
 Are my promotion criteria inclusive of different leadership approaches? 
 
2️⃣ 
Audit Performance Reviews for Bias
Unconscious bias creeps into performance evaluations. Asian employees, for example, may be praised for technical skills but overlooked for strategic thinking or leadership potential. 
Solution:
 Conduct bias audits in your review and promotion processes. Ensure that growth opportunities aren’t based on assumptions but on demonstrated impact and potential. 
 
3️⃣ 
Create Sponsorship, Not Just Mentorship
Mentorship is great, but sponsorship is a game-changer. Sponsors actively 
advocate
 for employees, recommending them for high-visibility projects and leadership roles. 
Action Step:
 Pair underrepresented employees with senior leaders who can advocate for their growth—not just offer advice. 
 
4️⃣ 
Foster a Culture Where All Voices Are Heard
Employees who don’t fit the traditional leadership mold may hesitate to speak up in meetings—especially if they’ve been conditioned to stay in the background. 
Solution:
 
Encourage psychological safety in meetings. Actively invite different perspectives, and ensure that contributions are valued—not dismissed or overlooked. 
 
5️⃣ 
Offer Cultural Competence Training
The best way to tackle unconscious bias? 
Awareness and education.
 Provide ongoing training that helps managers and employees recognize and challenge stereotypes in real time. 
 
 
🎯
 
Need a customized approach? Let’s talk.
Breaking free from “positive” stereotypes isn’t just about fairness—it’s about unlocking the full potential of your workforce. Let’s discuss how you can implement these strategies in your organization.  
Schedule a complimentary call with me today, and let’s start building a truly inclusive leadership pipeline.
 
 
 
📅
 
Book Your Complimentary Call Now
 
 
 
Bye for now, 
Luiza
___________________________________
 
Luiza Dreasher, Founder and CEO (she/her/hers)
Mastering Cultural Differences 
I work with leaders who want to create a work environment where all employees feel valued and want to stay.
At 
Mastering Cultural Differences LLC,
 we are committed to helping organizations build inclusive, culturally competent workplaces where every individual feels valued and respected. Through highly customized programs, we equip teams with knowledge and skills to help them connect and collaborate more effectively across differences. subject: How to thrive at the intersection of accessibility and technology with Mandy Harvey
body:
Golden Buzzer pick on America’s Got Talent, Mandy Harvey joins the Power of Inclusion Summit April 21-24
 
 
Learn how to thrive at the intersection of accessibility and technology with Mandy Harvey!
 
 
Mandy Harvey has experienced the profound difference in navigating the world as both a hearing person and as a deaf person. Join us as she shares her powerful journey 
exploring the intersection of technology and accessibility
, and how innovation is not only breaking down barriers for people with disabilities, but uplifting everyone in the process.
 
Mandy has performed on one of the biggest stages in the world. Her story illustrates how the power of inclusion, and embracing who she is, allowed her to thrive onstage and in life.
 
We are excited to have Mandy as one of our Keynote Speakers at the 
2025 Justice for All Summit: The Power of Inclusion.
Reserve Your Seat
 
More about Mandy:
Mandy Harvey is a singer, songwriter, author, and speaker who happens to be deaf. Mandy was Simon Cowell‘s “Golden Buzzer” pick on America’s Got Talent. The video has collectively received over 500 million views. Mandy uses her talents and artistry to encourage others which can be seen by her many acts as part of nonprofit organizations such as No Barriers USA and work for “Music: Not Impossible” with Not Impossible Labs. Her heart is to help others achieve their dreams by encouraging them to “Try” and move forward as a community. Mandy Harvey was most recently featured in the documentary, "Hero." The documentary challenges the notion that heroes possess superhuman abilities, emphasizing that everyone can be the hero of their own story by unlocking their innate potential. Mandy has also been featured in NBC Nightly News, Great Big Story, Vacations of the Brave, Music: Not Impossible (Not Impossible Labs), The LA Times, Dr. Oz, Pickler & Ben, America’s Got Talent, TODAY, Access Hollywood, Steve Harvey, and more.
Register Now
 
More about The 2025 Justice for All Summit: The Power of Inclusion
 
What is the Justice for All Summit?
The third annual Justice for All Summit, being held April 21-24, 2025, is the premier virtual conference to connect, get inspired, and learn innovative strategies for cultural transformation through diversity, equity, inclusion, and justice practices.
Who attends?
This restorative space brings together between 500 - 750 HR practitioners, executives, team leaders, learning and development staff, corporate trainers, organizational development professionals, and diversity practitioners in community for learning, networking, and personal/professional development.
 
Who is The Winters Group?
Proudly Black women-owned and -led, The Winters Group has helped organizations strategically increase their capacity to be more culturally competent, create sustainable equitable policies, and foster inclusive workplaces since 1984.
Reserve Your Seat
 
 
 
 
 
The Winters Group, 8116 South Tryon Street, Ste. B3-260, Charlotte, North Carolina 28273, United States

subject: Business case for Faith employee resource groups 🚩
body:
HSBC Bank has a Global Faith Network
 
 
Business case for Faith employee resource groups (ERGs)
 
Dear Larry Baker, 
A new "
Global ERG Impact Report
" by Radius Networks highlights the crucial role Employee Resource Groups (ERGs) play in organizations. The study interviewed more than 1,400 global companies across Asia-Pacific, Europe, the Middle East, and Africa.
The report highlights the impact of leveraging employee networks' lived experiences to reach new customers, from facilitating discussions on faith and finance in APAC to enhancing social mobility in EMEA and amplifying employee voices in the Americas.
Business Impact of HSBC’s Global Faith Network
 
Jack Guest, HSBC’s Senior Group Inclusion Advisor, emphasizes in the report that employee networks are not just about fostering belonging within the workplace—they are key drivers of meaningful change both inside and outside the organization. Employee Faith Network Drive Change Within and Beyond the Workplace
The report discusses how HSBC’s Global Faith Network is reshaping the bank’s approach to understanding and adapting to a variety of religious perspectives on finance.
 
“For many of our markets, faith is a really important factor when it comes to how people think about money”, says Jack in the 
report
. “Our employee networks have helped us to understand and respond to these nuanced perspectives, which has in turn strengthened our reputation as a bank that understands its customers.” 
The report notes that employee networks have transformed the way this commercial and personal bank engages with its community. By organizing events tied to festivals such as Eid, Diwali, and Hanukkah, these networks foster multi-faith understanding, with HSBC’s Country CEOs in attendance.
“Clients and customers say that our faith events help them to feel valued”, says Jack. “They allow us to build deeper relationships which we couldn’t achieve without our networks.” 
 
And when employees are allowed to bring their faith and belief identities to work, this 
"builds" religious freedom for all
 by expanding the space where faith and beliefs are welcomed as valuable sources of inspiration and resiliency. Check out related resources below.
Brian Grim
President
Religious Freedom & Business Foundation 
Registration Open (London & Washington DC)
 
 
 
In the News
 
 
In some of the United States' largest companies, religious affinity groups—formed by employees of various faiths—serve as spaces for dialogue and advocacy. U.S. employers are required to accommodate employees' religious practices. By Alexis Buisson. 
Read more
. 
Research
 
 
 
Many workplace leaders avoid addressing religion explicitly for fear of conflict. But Ecklund, Daniels, and Scheitle argue that ignoring religion’s presence at work can cause more harm than good. This is the case because many employees 
want
 to express or practice their faith at work as part of bringing their authentic selves to work, and they feel excluded or stifled if discouraged from doing so. 
Read more
.  
The Power of Jewish ERGs: Findings From Clal’s Research Report, Jewish at Work 2024
 
 
Demand for Jewish ERGs is Growing: The movement for Jewish ERGs is gaining momentum, with 46% of new members joining since October 7, 2023. For 24% of participants, their company’s ERG is their primary connection to Jewish life—a powerful testament to the role these groups play in fostering identity and belonging. 
Read more
.

subject: Youth Workers and their fresh perspective on inclusion
body:
📅 
Happenings
FREE WEBINAR NEXT WEEK - BOLSTER YOUR ERG STRATEGY
 -
 
Join us for a free open webinar, THIS MONDAY 
Mar. 17th at 12pm ET
. During this webinar we will chat through how to revamp your ERG strategy and share best practices. We’ll cover best practices and the current status of company ERGs, a case study for an ERG strategy refresh, and ideas to engage ALLIES in your organization’s ERGs. 
Register for free here
.
INTERNATIONAL ALLYSHIP DAY
 - Join us in NYC or virtually on August 8th for our 
2nd annual International Allyship Day event
, hosted by our partner AllianceBernstein. This year’s focus is on equipping inclusion and ERG leaders with actionable strategies to strengthen or launch allyship programs within their organizations. Participants will gain essential skills for effective allyship, pushback-proof strategies, and insights into the strategic business impact of allyship. They’ll also have the chance to connect with senior leaders in the inclusion space. We're consistently adding exciting new speakers and organizations like Coqual and Dr. Sandra Upton - 
will your organization be there?
 
Register individually or as a team here
.
​
 
​
📝 Youth Workers and their fresh perspective on inclusion
Our team started the week this week at the National Afterschool Association conference with youth workers. I facilitated an opening session on the current state of diversity, equity and inclusion with tools to develop the next generation of little allies. The conversations at the conference were very mixed on the state of inclusion... Some extremely passionate, some fearful and a lot of people in between. 
Similar to the conversations we're having in corporate spaces, diversity is a fact. Diverse representation is a reality. However, the pushback is also real. Many commented that their superintendents or leaders were preventing them from talking about inclusion issues with children.
Inclusion is the way forward. Accepting the status quo is exclusionary. When we quiet allies, we are promoting exclusion. 
In my session, like our client sessions, I used a polling exercise for anonymous sharing. One of the questions I asked is, 
"Why is it important to have this conversation about inclusion earlier?".
 It always brings me such joy to see the responses:
I want all children to feel safe.
I wish I'd had these conversations earlier.
Everyone deserves to feel included. 
I want a better world for future generations. 
I know what it's like to feel excluded and I don't want that for other people. 
Our work is definitely at a pivot point. Even if it feels risky to bring up social justice or issues of inclusion, do it afraid. Have the courage to be the ally someone needs you to be right now. 
I get it. I know I'm channeling a lot of courage right now too. Take care of yourself. This is going to be a long game. 
Thanks allies,
Julie
P.S. I also had the chance to facilitate a team building session with my 11-year-old, Jane's soccer team about communication and team values. I thought it was really sweet that they sent this thank you note. There's so much hope around us when we look for it.
​
​
💬 
Allyship Conversation Starters & Resources
An excellent free webinar on 
Sustaining Impact in a Shifting Legal Landscape
​
 held by Lily Zheng, Kenji Yoshino and David Glasgow.
 
A 
g
rowing list of corporations
 that have publicly stated their commitments to diversity, equity and inclusion initiatives.
Care about inclusion for the little ones in your life? Check out the programs and resources from 
LITTLE ALLIES
, a nonprofit working to facilitate inclusive experiences for all children to feel seen, heard, and belong.
​
Next Pivot Point
 
works to promote allyship and inclusion across all dimensions of diversity in the workplace to make sure everyone feels seen, heard, and belonging at work.
​
Next Pivot Point
​

subject: The science of failure (and success)
body:
Plus: what to wear and what it says about you. 
March 12, 2025  ·  
View in browser
 
The Insightful Leader
BY 
KELLOGG INSIGHT
Leadership advice from the Kellogg School of Management at Northwestern University
Good morning,
Behind every great success story lie even greater tales of failure. Steven Spielberg was rejected from film school three times. Oprah Winfrey was fired from her first anchor job. There’s a good reason this has become something of a valuable cliché.
Setbacks can be a crucial part of young professionals’ development, according to research from Kellogg’s 
Ben Jones
 and 
Dashun Wang
. More on that this week.
Plus, if, like me, you're readying yourself for spring cleaning, consider a few words of advice about your work wardrobe from Kellogg’s 
Ellen Taaffe
.
The science of failure and success
Failure has become a kind of essential ingredient for professional development. A Google News search of just the last week brings up hundreds of articles discussing some form of professional failure: lessons learned from the failed SpaceX launch at 
NPR
, for example, or how to handle rejection in goal setting at 
Vox
.
What’s the appeal? Taking steps to learn from failure can pay dividends in the long run.
Just last week, 
Forbes
 discussed five ways setbacks can fuel career success, highlighting Jones and Wang’s 
2019 study of grant applications
. Jones and Wang examined a dataset of 778,291 R01 NIH grants between 1990 and 2005—NIH’s oldest and most common grant type and hugely important to early career researchers in the biomedical sciences. Then the team determined which grants fell just short of receiving funding (“near miss” grants) and which managed to squeak past the cutoff point (“narrow wins”). And to figure out just how much of a difference these early successes or setbacks made to a scientific career, the researchers traced the careers of 623 near-miss and 561 narrow-win scientists.
They found that scientists in the near-miss group were more likely to have “hit” papers (that is, papers that cracked the top-five percent of citations in a particular field and year). The team’s analysis also suggests that the act itself of failing may have pushed the frustrated scientists to improve.
“The advice to persevere is common,” 
says Jones in 
Kellogg Insight
. “But the idea that you take something valuable from the loss—and are better for it—is surprising and inspiring.”
Read more about the research in 
Kellogg Insight
. (Plus enjoy additional research and insights on the upsides of failure 
here
.)
 
What to wear—and what it says about you
The decision on how to dress is one of many that we make every day, despite it seeming to have nothing to do with our jobs. It’s a decision about how we want to be seen, or not seen, by our bosses and coworkers and clients. On a recently re-released The Insightful Leader 
podcast
, Kellogg’s Ellen Taaffe reflects on those dilemmas. She thinks 
a lot
 about the question of how we present ourselves.
Before Kellogg, she was a brand-management executive at PepsiCo, Whirlpool, and Royal Caribbean. While on one sales team, her boss asked her not to wear red. She didn’t want to wear black or navy—it didn’t suit her. So finally, she decided to go her own way.
“I think it definitely was a time when I was gathering my courage. To, a little bit, go against what my boss had said,” says Taaffe. “But I can remember one particular meeting when I did lay out my clothes the night before. It was just this feeling of, I don't know what his reaction is, but this is who I am.”
It can take courage to let your identity show at work. And sometimes, it might be smart to reign it in a little—at least for a while.
For more on how you should present yourself at work, listen to Taaffe and Kellogg’s 
Derek Rucker
 on 
The Insightful Leader podcast
.
“It is really important for people to have a clear understanding that programs like Medicaid are essential for a functioning society.”
— 
Lauren Rivera
, in 
Yahoo! Finance
, on the potential impact of cutting government healthcare programs like Medicaid.
Have a wonderful week!
Blake Goble, marketing manager
Kellogg Insight
Follow us on 
LinkedIn
.
And listen to our 
podcasts
.
Kellogg School of Management
 | 
2211 Campus Drive
, 
Evanston, IL 60208

subject: The Federal Government’s Slow-Motion Train Wreck (Wise Decision Maker Guide 146)
body:
Wise Decision Maker Guide 
 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
Greetings Larry,
The Trump administration has initiated what may become the most devastating dismantling of the federal workforce in modern history, not with mass firings, but with a carefully designed invitation to resign. The recently announced deferred resignation program, introduced via an Office of Personnel Management (OPM) memo, offers federal employees a lucrative off-ramp: full pay and benefits until September 30, 2025, with exemption from in-person work requirements, and many put on administrative leave. 
Many will take this offer. Facing mounting uncertainty, a hostile workplace environment, and the erosion of once-ironclad civil service protections, thousands of employees will see this as their best—or perhaps only—chance to leave on their own terms before being pushed out under harsher conditions later. Those most likely to accept the offer? The most experienced, highly skilled federal employees who know their value and have private-sector options.
 The consequences of this mass departure will not be felt immediately. That’s what makes this such a dangerous, slow-moving disaster.
To learn more, check out this 
blog
.
Read Blog
 
Prefer video to text? See this 
video
 based on the blog:
If you prefer audio, listen to this 
podcast
 based on the blog:
Make Your Voice Heard
Vote in this 
LinkedIn poll
 to contribute to the conversation. I will use the responses to inform my articles in 
Harvard Business Review
, 
Fortune
, and 
Entrepreneur
.
Your Testimonials
You and others who gain value from Disaster Avoidance Experts 
services
 and thought leadership occasionally share testimonials about your experience, such as the one below. You can read more testimonials 
here
.
"Dr. Gleb Tsipursky presented [to] senior executive leaders and practitioners from throughout the region. The audience was 
very appreciative of the informative content and inspired by Dr. Gleb’s engaging and dynamic speaking style. Everyone benefited from the real-life, useful 'takeaways' that they could implement into their own work life right away.
 The feedback was universally positive with many people commenting that they had received 
tremendous value in return for their time in attending the three-hour program.
 There have been several requests that Dr. Gleb be invited back again soon."
David Cutri
, Vice President Northwest Ohio ISACA Chapter, and Secretary Northwest Ohio IIA Chapter
Schedule a Free Consultation
 
What's Up With Me
It's been really hard to see the situation with my fatherland of Ukraine. Military assistance cut off, and even intelligence cut off. I'll be traveling to New York later this week to visit my parents for my mom's 75th birthday, and I feel ashamed in front of my dad, who is 84, and was born in Ukraine (my mom was born in Moldova). I anticipate some hard conversations about how he's feeling about the country he immigrated to with my mom and me in 1991, after his homeland was freed from Russian domination. All this time, America served as a bastion of freedom and defense against tyranny, and my dad was proud to live here and taught me to be proud of America. What's happening right now feels like a betrayal, and the long-term consequences will be dire, with our allies around the world no longer being able to count on us and thus failing to support us when we need them. In fact, the only time the NATO alliance's self-defense clause was invoked involved the attack on the US on 9/11, when the US needed help in Afghanistan. What we're seeing is truly a slow-moving train wreck, of promises broken and allies betrayed.
Would love to get your feedback on what you found most useful about this edition of the “Wise Decision Maker Guide” - simply reply to this email.
Decisively Yours,
Dr. Gleb
Dr. Gleb Tsipursky
CEO of Disaster Avoidance Experts
PS: Are we connected on LinkedIn? If not, 
please add me
.

(New Harbinger, 2020)

subject: What’s New at Zoom | February 2025 Recap
body:
Learn more about what makes Zoom Docs and AI Companion the perfect match! Dear Valued Customer, As Zoom evolves, we want to help you stay up to date on how the latest products and features can help
 
Learn more about what makes Zoom Docs and AI Companion the perfect match! 
 
Dear Valued Customer,
 
  
As Zoom evolves, we want to help you stay up to date on how the latest products and features can help you work and collaborate better. We’ll outline some highlights below, including opportunities for further learning.
 
  
To get more detailed information about the latest releases, here are a few resources: 
 
Zoom Digital Customer Success Hub
 - This event hub is full of training and information sessions hosted by the Zoom Digital Customer Success team. 
 
What’s New at Zoom blog
 - The blog is a great spot to keep up with Zoom, and the What’s New post is regularly updated with info about new products and features. 
 
Preview notes
 - A list of upcoming features. This page is only available to Zoom account owners and admins; you must sign in to view them.
 
Release notes
 - A complete list of past releases across the Zoom platform. 
 
  
If you have questions about the features and announcements outlined below, please reply directly to this email.
 
 
*Note: Some products and features may not be available to all customers.
 
Events & Training
Navigating legal and privacy challenges in AI implementation
 - 
AI adoption is transforming businesses, but responsible implementation is key to maintaining security, privacy, and compliance. Watch the on-demand recording of Cheree McAlpine, Chief Legal Officer at Zoom, and Hanan Szwarcbord, VP & Chief Security Officer at Micron Technology, as they share best practices for implementing AI within your organization. Szwarcbord discusses how he worked with legal and compliance teams on Micron’s journey to enabling Zoom AI Companion, while McAlpine provides her perspective on AI as a CLO’s standpoint. 
 
Introducing Zoom Workflow Automation
Zoom Workflow Automation is now generally available! Think of how much time you spend on routine work tasks, like sending a weekly check-in message or duplicating information from one application to another. What may seem like a minute here or there can quickly add up when you have more meaningful projects you’d rather get to. Zoom’s new Workflow Automation can help you get that valuable time back.
 
This powerful tool streamlines work across Zoom Workplace and third-party apps, and leverages AI Companion to summarize and provide actionable insights. With it, you can trigger actions, integrate with external tools, and automate responses based on user interactions, such as emoji reactions. For example, you can keep teams aligned and organized by automatically adding AI Companion meeting summaries to a dedicated Zoom Doc that is then shared in a chat channel!
 
Workflow Automation is now available to paid Zoom users at no additional cost during the free trial period. Visit our support pages to learn how to 
enable
 and 
use
 Workflow Automation. Users must be on Zoom Workplace app to version 6.3.10 or higher to access this feature. And click the button below 
for an overview of what Workflow Automation can do for you!
Learn More About Workflow Automation
 
 
 
How Zoom AI Companion Can Help You
The day-to-day work of an IT administrator looks very different from their colleagues in the marketing department, but Zoom AI Companion can help both of these groups work more efficiently — and they aren’t the only ones!
 
 
Whether you’re already a daily AI Companion user or still thinking about taking the leap, we wanted to provide some inspiration to help you find new ways this powerful tool can streamline your daily tasks. Check out these new step-by-step use cases showing AI Companion workflows for users in IT, marketing, sales, HR, product and project management, and much more. Feel free to share this resource with your Zoom end users!
Explore AI Companion Use Cases
 
 
Service Updates
 
Zoom Software Lifecycle Policy -
 While the next regular Software Lifecycle Policy enforcement date is May 3, 2025, Zoom has decided to maintain the current minimum version requirements that were established for the February 1, 2025, enforcement. Please continue to check our 
support article
 for the table of products and corresponding minimum versions. As always, we highly recommend you regularly download and update to the latest version of Zoom software by checking for updates within the Zoom app or by navigating to 
zoom.us/download
 to take advantage of all our latest security and functionality features.
Zoom firewall settings -
 
Zoom is continuously optimizing our global footprint to improve performance and availability for our customers. Customers should not need to perform any active changes provided they are following the guidance as provided in our support article 
“Network Firewall Settings for CRC and Enhanced API Connector.”
 For any questions or concerns, please contact your account team or 
Zoom Support
.
Catch us on social 
 
You're receiving this email because you are a Zoom customer. 
 
If you wish to be removed from our email list, 
unsubscribe
 or 
manage your email preferences.

subject: Trusaic & WorldatWork: Pay Equity vs. Pay Gap Reporting
body:
Join us for a deep dive into pay equity and pay transparency reporting.
 
 
Dear Larry,
 
Are you interested in addressing pay inequities more proactively? Join us for our webinar with WorldatWork 
at 9 a.m. PT,  March 19
, where Trusaic’s Gail Greenfield, Aon’s Alessandro Linari, and Workday’s Denise Williams will deep-dive into pay equity and pay gap reporting.
 
Attendees will learn:
The key differences between compensation data and payroll data.
Why payroll data should never be used for remediating pay inequities.
How to proactively address pay inequities through compensation data analysis before submitting pay gap reports.
The role of contextual narratives in minimizing risk and providing clarity to employees, regulators, and the public.
Actionable insights to improve pay reporting processes and promote pay equity.
Register today for this insightful webinar!
Register Now
 
 
Trusaic, 520 S Grand Ave, Suite 200, Los Angeles, CA 90071, United States, 213-382-1115

subject: 🚨 The Hidden Cost of “Positive” Stereotypes in the Workplace
body:
Continue reading to learn more about the impact of stereotypes in the workplace. ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Hello Larry!
 
🛑
 
Picture this:
Imagine a high-performing employee on your team—let’s call her Mei. Mei is incredibly detail-oriented, excellent with numbers, and rarely speaks up in meetings. Leadership views her as a “perfect team player” because she never challenges decisions or takes risks. She’s frequently praised for being diligent, but when it comes to promotions, Mei is passed over. The assumption? She’s not “leadership material.” 
 
🤔
 
The Experience:
For many professionals—especially those from underrepresented backgrounds—so-called 
“positive” stereotypes
 create invisible barriers. For example, Asian Americans are seen as technically gifted but lacking leadership presence. Black women are assumed to be strong and resilient, but not “warm” enough for executive roles. Women in general are praised for being collaborative but criticized when they assert authority. 
These stereotypes may seem complimentary, but they 
box employees in
, limiting opportunities and stalling careers. 
 
⚠️
 
The Problem:
When organizations unknowingly reinforce these biases, they:
🚧
 Fail to recognize diverse leadership styles, narrowing their talent pipeline.
🚧
 Create disengagement as employees feel unseen or undervalued.
🚧
 Lose out on innovation and diverse perspectives that drive business success. 
And when employees feel trapped by stereotypes, inclusion remains an illusion.
 
 
💡
 
The Future You’re Waiting For:
Now, imagine a workplace where every employee—regardless of race, gender, or background—is seen for their 
unique strengths and leadership potential.
 A workplace where diverse perspectives thrive, and opportunities are based on 
capabilities, not assumptions.
 
That kind of inclusive culture isn’t just possible—it’s necessary for long-term success. 
 
🎤
 
What’s Next:
In my next email, I’ll share 
specific strategies
 to break free from these “positive” stereotypes and foster a truly inclusive workplace. Watch your inbox for actionable steps to drive real change. 
 
 
Bye for now, 
Luiza
___________________________________
 
Luiza Dreasher, Founder and CEO (she/her/hers)
Mastering Cultural Differences 
I work with leaders who want to create a work environment where all employees feel valued and want to stay.
At 
Mastering Cultural Differences LLC,
 we are committed to helping organizations build inclusive, culturally competent workplaces where every individual feels valued and respected. Through highly customized programs, we equip teams with knowledge and skills to help them connect and collaborate more effectively across differences. This email and any attachments are intended solely for the recipient(s) and may contain confidential or legally privileged information. Any unauthorized review, use, disclosure, or distribution is prohibited. If you received this email in error, please notify the sender immediately and delete it from your system. We respect your privacy. Please note you also have the right to opt out of emails at any time via the link at the bottom of our emails. If you have any questions about this Privacy Policy or need assistance managing your personal information, feel free to contact us at: 
www.masteringculturaldifferences.com
 or by sending an email to 
luiza@masteringculturaldifferences.com
.

1350 Sextant Avenue West • Roseville, MN • 55113-3134

subject: 5 Things: Chicagoland's Weekly Business Update
body:
Delivered by Southwest Airlines 
 
Click 
here
 
to view this email in your browser.
 
 
 
 
 
Weekly Business Update 
March 10, 2025
Delivered by
 
THE EXCHANGE
Introducing Chamber Chats: In-Depth Business Insights at The Exchange 2025
PRESENTED BY THE CHICAGOLAND CHAMBER OF COMMERCE
 
The Exchange 2025, presented by Southwest Airlines, is introducing Chamber Chats, 20-minute interactive sessions designed to provide practical insights on real-world business challenges. Representatives from Robert Half will discuss key workforce trends, offering strategies for hiring, retention, and talent development, while professionals from ALERA Group will break down the complexities of small business health insurance, providing data-driven strategies to navigate rising costs and evolving regulations. Don’t miss these valuable discussions at Chicago’s largest networking event on April 10. For a limited time, bring the whole squad by purchasing 4 tickets for the price of 3!
LEARN MORE
 
MEMBER NEWS
You’re Invited: Exclusive Business Networking Event! 
PRESENTED BY PILLUR
 
Join us for Pillur’s Grand Opening Happy Hour on March 12 from 4 to 6 p.m. at their new Wicker Park location! Network with top business leaders, take advantage of exclusive business banking perks designed for entrepreneurs and startups, and enjoy live entertainment hosted by Nikki from 101.9 THE MIX Chicago. Plus, don’t miss special promotions and exciting giveaways! The event will be held at 2234 W North Ave, Chicago, IL 60647. Formal remarks begin at 4:30 p.m.
REGISTER NOW
 
UPCOMING EVENT
Make Your Next Professional Connection at Nisos Prime on March 19 
PRESENTED BY THE CHICAGOLAND CHAMBER OF COMMERCE
 
Attend the Chicagoland Chamber of Commerce’s Business After Business networking event hosted by Nisos Prime on March 19. Attendees will have the opportunity to network with local professionals within a distinctive warm and welcoming hospitality, set against a stunningly designed backdrop. Business After Business, the Chamber’s monthly networking happy hours, ensure you make the connections you need — and want — to grow your business.
REGISTER NOW
 
MEMBER NEWS
Work Perks: Last Chance for Chamber Members to Get Special Rate for Blackhawks Tickets 
PRESENTED BY THE CHICAGO BLACKHAWKS
 
Don't miss your chance to catch the action live—grab these exclusive end-of-season ticket specials for the Chicago Blackhawks through Work Perks using promo code “CHAMBER”! With tickets starting at just $25/$30 for most games, this is your perfect opportunity to experience the excitement at the United Center while cheering on the Hawks.
LEARN MORE
 
SMALL BUSINESS
Chicago BACP to Host Remote Small Business Expo on March 27 
PRESENTED BY THE CITY OF CHICAGO BACP
 
Join the Chicago Department of Business Affairs and Consumer Protection (BACP) for the Small Business Expo on March 27, from 9 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. This free, virtual event connects entrepreneurs with valuable resources, expert insights, and funding opportunities to start or grow their business in Chicago. Attend workshops, network with industry professionals, and gain access to business licensing consultants, financial advisors, and more.
LEARN MORE
 
Want to showcase your company news, information, products, or services?
 
Chamber members are able to take advantage of a myriad of benefits to help your business grow, including inclusion in this email newsletter. With a broad distribution, you can gain access to a new audience that you may not otherwise be able to reach.

subject: Your Questions Answered: Executive Orders and Compliance
body:
Now is the time to amplify your efforts with proven expertise. 
 
 
Recent executive orders (EOs) have raised pressing questions about their implications in the workplace — and HR professionals need clear, reliable guidance to address these questions effectively. 
Join SHRM today
 to engage with SHRM experts as they provide insights, actionable guidance, and key considerations to help you prepare your workplace with confidence. Whether you’re navigating compliance challenges, workplace policies, or operational shifts, this webinar will equip you with the knowledge and tools you need to adapt and lead effectively. 
A 
SHRM membership
 will give you immediate access to our EO Impact Zone and First 100 Days hub pages, compliance resources, expert analysis, and strategies to help you stay compliant, safeguard your teams, and adapt to change without missing a step. 
Webinar attendees will also receive 1 PDC toward SHRM-CP
®
 or SHRM-SCP
®
 recertification.
 
 
 
JOIN SHRM
 
 
Key Takeaways
 
Implications of Executive Orders:
 Understanding their impact on the workplace. 
 
HR Guidance:
 Clear, reliable insights to address workplace challenges. 
 
Compliance and Policy Support:
 Assistance with navigating legal and operational shifts. 
Opportunity for Engagement:
 A chance to interact with industry leaders and gain clarity. 
 
REGISTER NOW
 
 
Meet the Speakers
 
 
 
 
Jim Link, SHRM-SCP
CHRO, SHRM
Jim Link is the CHRO at SHRM. In his most recent role as CHRO for Randstad North America, Link led a global team of 150 HR professionals who were instrumental in transforming the company into an award-winning, inclusive, and sustainable global leader.
 
 
 
 
Tamla Oates-Forney
CEO, SHRM Linkage 
Tamla Oates-Forney is the CEO of SHRM Linkage, a global leadership development firm committed to advancing women and accelerating inclusion in leaders and organizations. She is an innovative thought leader, speaker, women’s advocate, wellness champion, philanthropist, and investor. 
 
 
 
 
Anuradha Hebbar, J.D.
President, SHRM CEO Action for Inclusion & Diversity
Anuradha Hebbar is the president of SHRM CEO Action for Inclusion & Diversity. She is a strategic business leader and human capital executive with a demonstrated history of designing and executing transformational change in global, Fortune 500, midsize and private-equity-backed organizations.

subject: IMA is Hiring!
body:
IMA is Hiring!
 
View this email in your browser
 
 
Hello Mentoring Community,
I have some exciting news to share!
The 
International Mentoring Association (IMA) is hiring!
 
As many of you know, I have the honor of serving as the 
President of the IMA
, and I’m thrilled to announce that we have 
two open positions
:
Coordinator for Publications and Communication
 – A key role in managing and enhancing IMA’s communication strategies, publications, and digital presence. 
Click here
 for more information and how to apply.
Vision Implementation Grants Intern
 – A unique opportunity to support the execution of IMA’s vision, assist in securing funding, and engage with mentoring leaders on a global scale. 
Click here
 for more information and how to apply.
If you’re passionate about mentoring and looking for a meaningful opportunity to make an impact, we’d love to hear from you!
The 
International Mentoring Association
 
(IMA) is dedicated to advancing mentoring excellence by providing resources, research, and best practices that support individuals and organizations worldwide. If you or someone in your network is interested in contributing to this mission, please share this opportunity!
Looking forward to welcoming new talent to our team!
 
Best,
Lisa
CEO, Center for Mentoring Excellence
President, International Mentoring Association

subject: Celebrating International Women’s Day: March Forward for Gender Equality
body:
Hi Larry,
This International Women's Day, we are inspired by the theme 
"March Forward"
—a reminder that gender equity is not a destination but a journey. It’s a call to continue moving forward, breaking barriers, and driving change for the better.
 
Today, we celebrate the women who lead, innovate, and pave the way for future generations. But we also acknowledge that our progress depends on the collective effort to invest in women. 
 
At the heart of this progress is the 
ripple effect
—investing in women doesn’t just empower them; it sparks a 
broader transformation that enhances performance, innovation, and organisational success for everyone.
 
When we support women’s growth and leadership, we create positive momentum that extends beyond the individual, touching entire teams and entire companies. This ripple effect is one of the most powerful ways to drive inclusivity, and it’s something we should continue to invest in, each and every day.
 
Let’s continue to make strides towards a gender-equal world.
 
SCHEDULE TIME TO TALK
 
LEARN MORE
 
Symmetra Pty Ltd, Quay Quarter Towers, Level 2, 50 Bridge Street, Sydney, NSW 2000 Australia, hello@symmetraglobal.com

It was incredibly powerful, and I know I’ll be approaching candidate screens with a much more intentional mindset. I can promise you this—I’ll never let “culture fit” go unquestioned again without asking, “What did you mean by that?” Those two short hours truly shifted my perspective, and I’m so grateful to you for that. 
If you're interested, here’s a bit more about the organization Charles founded: 
4Kira4Moms – Who We Are
. Kira’s story is a painful but powerful example of how bias in healthcare can have real, life-or-death consequences. 
I really appreciated our discussion today, and this was a story that came to mind as a real-world illustration of why this work is absolutely essential. 
Thanks again for such a powerful session!
All my best,
Laura (the “needlepointer” 
😉
 )
 
 
Laura Ladi
 
(she/her/hers)
Spencer Stuart
 San Francisco
T 415-808-8909 | M 858-229-4355

Leadership for a Complex World: Planning for the CEO of the Future

subject: Your roadmap for navigating difficult conversations
body:
Transform the way you lead with this award-winning book and program from the workplace experts
 
People often wish they had a roadmap for navigating difficult conversations. 
And that's exactly what we created.
The second edition of the award-winning 
We Can't Talk about That at Work
 by Mary-Frances Winters and Mareisha N. Winters Reese offers step-by-step guidance for turning conflict into constructive conversation and increasing teamwork, productivity, engagement, and overall well-being.
The proven frameworks in this book are also the basis for TWO leadership development programs:
🌟 
Engaging in Bold, Inclusive Conversations® Certification Program
: a 3-day virtual certification program in June or September 2025
🌟 
We Can't Talk About That at Work! Mastering the Art of Navigating Polarizing Topics
: a 90-minute virtual session on March 12
Transform the way you lead by reading the book, earning your certification, and deepening your skillset for Bold, Inclusive Conversations®.
Join Our 3-Day Program
 
Attend Our 90-Min Session
 
Buy Your Copy of the Book
 
Meet the Authors and Experts
Mary-Frances Winters is the founder and CEO of The Winters Group, Inc. She was named a top ten diversity trailblazer by Forbes and a diversity pioneer by Profiles in Diversity Journal. She is the recipient of the prestigious ATHENA Award, the Winds of Change Award from the Forum on Workplace Inclusion, the 2023 Profiles in Diversity Journal Black Leadership Award, and the 2024 Empowering Equitable Change Award from the University of Rochester. Mary-Frances is also the author of 
Inclusive Conversations
, 
Black Fatigue
, and 
Racial Justice at Work
. 
 
Mareisha N. Winters Reese is president and COO of The Winters Group, Inc., and is a coauthor of 
Racial Justice at Work
. She was named to Diversity MBA’s Top 100 Under 50 Executive and Emerging Leaders and Diversity Woman Media’s The Power 100 List. In 2023, Mareisha was named a Who’s Who in Black Charlotte and was recognized in the Charlotte Business Journal’s Power 100 and Profiles in Diversity Journal’s Women Worth Watching. 
 
Start Building Inclusive Workplaces with The Winters Group Today
 
 
 
 
 
The Winters Group, 8116 South Tryon Street, Ste. B3-260, Charlotte, North Carolina 28273, United States

subject: More “Masculine Energy?” No thanks…Bring on the Lionesses.
body:
“You know, Mom, you’re like lionesses!”
 
 
 
My daughter and I were walking to school the other morning. Along the way, I exchanged greetings with several female neighbors. We exchanged brief words of encouragement, checked in on how things were going with family members and jobs, offered assistance with kids and meals.  
My daughter said, “You know, Mom, you’re like lionesses!” 
Now, for some context, my kid and I watch a lot of wildlife documentaries. Lions often represent the pinnacle of masculine strength, with the male lion being lauded as the “King of the Beasts.” But that moniker doesn’t give much credit to who’s really running the pride.
Unlike most animal species, lion prides are matriarchal. The females create a centralized, stable system around which the pride functions. Lionesses are deeply social and collaborative. They not only care for the cubs, they also do the majority of the hunting and are fierce defenders, taking on much larger predators to protect their pride. 
When leaders like Mark Zuckerberg complain that the corporate world has become 
“culturally neutered” and call for more  “masculine energy” in the workplace
, what they mean is a work culture that rewards behaviors that go 
against
 the cooperative mentality that makes a pride thrive - they're talking about aggressive, winner-take-all, competitive behaviors that drive isolation, not collaboration.
This is problematic for multiple reasons. 
It overlooks the fact that 
masculinity contest work cultures are counterproductive
, and not only that, 
women and men alike
 don’t actually like working in them.  Studies have shown that constructive organizational cultures are both humanistic and achievement-oriented. They reward healthy competition and constructive conflict as well as empathy, compassion, and collaboration. 
 
It contributes to the rising wave of toxic masculinity, which is not only backwards but dangerous. Global studies are finding that  
women are increasingly afraid of men
, and with good reason. Cases of assault, stalking, and violence against women and members of the trans community have increased dramatically in the last few years. In the US, there was a 
4600 percent increase in misogynistic speech in December 2024 following the November election
. For example, terms like, "Your body, my choice" and "Get back in the kitchen" increased exponentially on the social media platform X. 
 
It further diminishes women’s participation in what have been traditionally male-dominated industries and jobs, including science, technology, math, and engineering (STEM), finance, venture capital, law enforcement, and active combat. In all of these industries, women can and do play critical roles and are 
found to be equal in competence to their male counterparts
, and in some cases provide unique values because of their identity experiences. 
Women’s History Month is a opportunity to celebrate the great many accomplishments of women throughout the generations. Yet, it is also a call to action for all of us, 
including men
, to contribute to cultures that promote more collaboration and compassion alongside healthy competition. Ditch the bro culture, chainsaw wielding, “Go back to the kitchen” messages. They ultimately don’t serve anyone, not even the bros with the chainsaws. 
 
Maria Morukian
Founder and Chief Executive Officer
MSM Global Consulting
MSM GLOBAL UPDATES
 
This past month, Maria Morukian shared two insightful articles on LinkedIn that explore critical conversations shaping the future of diversity, equity, and inclusion. As organizations navigate evolving legal landscapes and push back against the false narratives surrounding merit and inclusion, these pieces from Harvard Business Review offer timely perspectives. Below, we summarize key takeaways from each article and why they matter for leaders committed to DEI as a strategic priority:
How to Assess the New Legal Risks of Your DEI Policies
As legal challenges to DEI policies become more prevalent, organizations must proactively assess risk while staying true to their commitment to equity. This HBR article provides a strategic framework for leaders to evaluate their DEI initiatives in light of evolving regulations. It outlines key legal considerations, including affirmative action rollbacks, new compliance expectations, and the importance of transparency in decision-making. Rather than retreating from DEI efforts, businesses are encouraged to refine their strategies which will ensure they align with both legal and ethical imperatives. The article underscores the need for ongoing education, legal consultation, and thoughtful adaptation to maintain inclusive workplaces without compromising compliance.
The False Dichotomy of Merit and Inclusion
One of the most persistent myths in DEI conversations is the idea that merit and inclusion are opposing forces. This article challenges that false dichotomy, arguing that diversity actually enhances merit by broadening the pool of talent and perspectives within an organization. The piece critiques outdated views of meritocracy, which often fail to account for systemic barriers that limit opportunity. By redefining merit to include diverse experiences and capabilities, businesses can cultivate stronger, more innovative teams. The takeaway? Inclusion isn’t, and has never been, about lowering standards. 
It’s about recognizing excellence in all its forms from diverse backgrounds and institutions.
 
Culture Stew
Last year we produced this episode, and  thought it was worth a reheat, especially considering the increasing challenges public educators face in supporting the needs of diverse students. Culturally fluent education is increasingly crucial to the future success of our children. In this episode of Culture Stew, Maria met with Dr. Ayanna F. Brown to explore the evolving landscape of equity in education. From systemic challenges to actionable strategies, Dr. Brown shares her insights on fostering meaningful change in schools and communities. Whether you're an educator, leader, or advocate, this conversation sheds light on the work needed to create inclusive learning environments that truly serve all students. 
Watch the full episode here: 
YouTube
Read more about the episode and listen to the podcast: 
MSM Global Consulting
Don’t forget to check out past episodes on our Culture Stew 
YouTube channel
! Subscribe and stay tuned for more conversations on diversity, equity, and inclusion.
Have you reviewed the Culture Stew Podcast yet? Please do! A short five star review can help get the podcast out to more viewers! 
MSM GLOBAL GALLERY
Here you can find curated content of current DEI issues and events for your further exploration.
 
How Americans See Men and Masculinity | Pew Research Center
A recent Pew Research Center study explored how Americans perceive the roles and expectations of men today. The findings highlight generational and ideological divides in attitudes toward traditional masculinity, emotional expression, and societal pressures on men. While many acknowledge the challenges men face, including mental health struggles and rigid gender norms, there is also growing support for redefining masculinity in ways that embrace vulnerability, caregiving, and emotional intelligence. This report provides valuable insight into how these shifting perspectives influence workplaces, relationships, and broader social dynamics.
Women leaders make work better. Here’s the science behind how to promote them.
Research from the American Psychological Association reveals that female leaders are not only breaking barriers but also transforming workplace cultures for the better. The study highlights how organizations with women in leadership roles tend to foster more inclusive, supportive, and equitable environments—benefiting employees across all demographics. Women leaders are more likely to implement policies that prioritize well-being, mentorship, and collaboration, ultimately driving higher engagement and performance. The article underscores the importance of diversifying leadership teams and challenging outdated biases about gender and leadership effectiveness.
  
We're waiting for you! 
Would you like to be a guest on the Culture Stew Podcast? 
Do you have a publication we can share on our newsletter or on our social media accounts? 
 
Contact us at 
CultureStew
@MSMGlobalConsulting.com
 TODAY! 
CONTENT FOR YOUR DOWN TIME
Here are some recommended articles and books for your down time.
 
Black Panther Woman
: The Political and Spiritual Life of 
Ericka Huggins
 (Black Power)
By 
 
Mary Frances Phillips
Ericka Huggins’ Black Panther Woman is a testament to the resilience, leadership, and revolutionary spirit of Black women in the fight for justice. As a key figure in the Black Panther Party, Huggins not only challenged racial and social oppression but also redefined the role of Black women in activism, balancing political resistance with spiritual resilience. Her story highlights the often-overlooked contributions of Black women in shaping movements, fostering community, and leading with both strength and compassion. In a world that seeks to silence them, Huggins’ life is a powerful reminder that Black women are, and always have been, at the forefront of change.
The Witch Boy
By 
Molly Knox Ostertag 
Molly Knox Ostertag’s The Witch Boy is a powerful tale of identity and self-discovery that can resonate deeply with transgender and gender-nonconforming readers. The main character, Aster, struggles against rigid gender roles, where boys must be shapeshifters and girls are witches, mirrors the experience of those who defy societal expectations to embrace their true selves. His journey is a testament to the courage it takes to live authentically, showing young readers that identity is personal, not prescribed. By challenging norms with warmth and magic,
The Witch Boy affirms that being yourself is not only possible but necessary.
 
About MSM Global
We specialize in organizational culture change by empowering organizations to achieve greater success through embracing equity, diversity and inclusivity. We provide a holistic approach to organizational development, team capacity building, and leadership development. Let us know what would be helpful for you in this newsletter.
Connect with us!

subject: RE: Following Up – Charles Johnson & Kira’s Story
body:
Laura,
 
Thank you for these kind words!! 
 
I always appreciate when people can express the specific impact that they encountered because of our interaction. I think that I have heard of this story. I will review the information closer to see if there are points that I can use in future sessions.
 
I will be sure to keep in touch with you-I can use your recruiting expertise!!
 
Best,
 
Larry
 
From:
 LLadi@SpencerStuart.com <LLadi@SpencerStuart.com> 
Sent:
 Thursday, March 6, 2025 1:47 PM
To:
 Larry Baker <l.baker@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Following Up – Charles Johnson & Kira’s Story
 
Hi Larry,
I wanted to thank you again for such a thoughtful and engaging session on uncovering bias. It was incredibly powerful, and I know I’ll be approaching candidate screens with a much more intentional mindset. I can promise you this—I’ll never let “culture fit” go unquestioned again without asking, “What did you mean by that?” Those two short hours truly shifted my perspective, and I’m so grateful to you for that. 
As promised, I wanted to share more about 
the story of Charles Johnson and his wife, Kira,
 and the work Charles is doing since Kira’s passing.
In 2016, Charles and Kira went to Cedars-Sinai for what should have been a routine C-section to welcome their second child. Kira was healthy, but after the delivery, she started showing signs of internal bleeding. Charles kept asking the medical team for help, but for more than 10 hours, his concerns were dismissed. At one point, a doctor said to him, “Sir, your wife is not a priority right now”. By the time she was finally taken into surgery, it was too late—Kira passed away from a hemorrhage that could have been prevented. Her death is one of far too many, as Black women in the U.S. are nearly three times more likely to die from pregnancy-related complications than white women.
After losing Kira, Charles founded 
4Kira4Moms
 (
4kira4moms.com
) to honor her memory and drive change in maternal healthcare. Through awareness campaigns, education, and legislative efforts, he’s helped pass key policies like the 
Preventing Maternal Deaths Act of 2018
 and the 
Protecting Moms Who Served Act of 2021
. He’s also a leading voice in the push for the 
Black Maternal Health Momnibus Act
, which takes a more comprehensive approach to addressing disparities in maternal care.
If you're interested, here’s a bit more about the organization Charles founded: 
4Kira4Moms – Who We Are
. Kira’s story is a painful but powerful example of how bias in healthcare can have real, life-or-death consequences. 
I really appreciated our discussion today, and this was a story that came to mind as a real-world illustration of why this work is absolutely essential. 
Thanks again for such a powerful session – I hope we can stay connected.
All my best,
Laura (the “needlepointer” 
😉
 )
 
 
Laura Ladi
 
(she/her/hers)
Spencer Stuart
 San Francisco
T 415-808-8909 | M 858-229-4355
Read our latest insights on leading at the top, 
Leadership for a Complex World: Planning for the CEO of the Future
 
This message is a private communication. It may contain information that is privileged or confidential. If you are not the intended recipient, please do not read, copy or use it, and do not disclose it to others. Please notify the sender of the delivery error by replying to this message, and then delete it and any attachments from your system. Please note your personal information and any additional information you have provided may be added to our proprietary database. For further information on how your personal data is collected, used, and transferred, please read our privacy policy on our website at 
https://www.spencerstuart.com/privacy
. If you have any questions on this topic you may contact 
privacy@spencerstuart.com
.

subject: Following Up – Charles Johnson & Kira’s Story
body:
Hi Larry,
I wanted to thank you again for such a thoughtful and engaging session on uncovering bias. It was incredibly powerful, and I know I’ll be approaching candidate screens with a much more intentional mindset. I can promise you this—I’ll never let “culture fit” go unquestioned again without asking, “What did you mean by that?” Those two short hours truly shifted my perspective, and I’m so grateful to you for that. 
As promised, I wanted to share more about 
the story of Charles Johnson and his wife, Kira,
 and the work Charles is doing since Kira’s passing.
In 2016, Charles and Kira went to Cedars-Sinai for what should have been a routine C-section to welcome their second child. Kira was healthy, but after the delivery, she started showing signs of internal bleeding. Charles kept asking the medical team for help, but for more than 10 hours, his concerns were dismissed. At one point, a doctor said to him, “Sir, your wife is not a priority right now”. By the time she was finally taken into surgery, it was too late—Kira passed away from a hemorrhage that could have been prevented. Her death is one of far too many, as Black women in the U.S. are nearly three times more likely to die from pregnancy-related complications than white women.
After losing Kira, Charles founded 
4Kira4Moms
 (
4kira4moms.com
) to honor her memory and drive change in maternal healthcare. Through awareness campaigns, education, and legislative efforts, he’s helped pass key policies like the 
Preventing Maternal Deaths Act of 2018
 and the 
Protecting Moms Who Served Act of 2021
. He’s also a leading voice in the push for the 
Black Maternal Health Momnibus Act
, which takes a more comprehensive approach to addressing disparities in maternal care.
If you're interested, here’s a bit more about the organization Charles founded: 
4Kira4Moms – Who We Are
. Kira’s story is a painful but powerful example of how bias in healthcare can have real, life-or-death consequences. 
I really appreciated our discussion today, and this was a story that came to mind as a real-world illustration of why this work is absolutely essential. 
Thanks again for such a powerful session – I hope we can stay connected.
All my best,
Laura (the “needlepointer” 
😉
 )
 
 
Laura Ladi
 
(she/her/hers)
Spencer Stuart
 San Francisco
